text: Originally rated on 2/12/09. Amber- copper body, thin head, with no lace. Aroma of toffe and caramel malts, decent mouthfeel. Flavor of sweet slightly toasted malts with a few hops peeking through, smooth with a decent balance. Overall a pretty good Irish Ale.

Short stubby bottle like the one pictured but the label is different, it says red ale prominently. Big malty aroma that follows a milder malty nose. First taste is aged ale like. Decent co2, but yes this is quite like an irish ale of the old country, I think. Difficult, does not hide its abv attribute, its there, get used to it. Reddish? Not too sure, its more like orange brown yellow, 314. Whew. Becomes a little difficult in the end, but it is beer.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Poured from a chilled 12 oz. brown bottle into a freshly cleansed pint glass. 
Aroma: slight barley roastiness. Look: dark, dark red with brown and tan clouds of thick, creamy head. Taste: Goodness in a pint full of it. Palate: Dryish.
Overall: A very enjoyable, very drinkable, hoist a toast up @ ya red irish ale.
Obviously, I am rating this out of season. Really not bad at all and would purchase again. Mostly roasty and slightly warming.

Poured into a mug, the appearance was a ruddy semi-dark burnt red color. Quickly dissipating fingers worth of white foamy head. Mild stringy lacing.
The aroma centers around some sweet nuts, caramel tones, light tofffee, some toast.
The flavor wraps all of those previously mentioned aromas together. Smooth dry malty sweet aftertaste leading into the finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fair sessionability about it. Medium carbonation. Malts create a nice smoothness on my tongue.
Overall, decent Irish red ale that I could have again.

Poured crystal clear copper amber with a tall foamy beige head initially. The head became more creamy as it settled and eventual just became a film. The aroma was primarily roasted malt, but not to strong. There was a bit of a yeasty bread scent too. The flavor was also mild, with some roasted malt and a hint of hops upfront. The finish was again mild with just a hint of hops on the finish. The beer was smooth and mild, nice color and easy drinking

bottle @ Whiteys / Lawrenceburg IN --- Aroma of malt. Clear brown cololr, off-white head that drops to a cover, strips of lace. Taste is lightly toasted malt that grows into a medium carbonated swallow, followed by light oak and mild hops. An enjoyable brew.
Amber pour, fluffy off-white head. Aroma is malty, as is the flavor. Mostly caramel, not too roasted. Its pretty straightforward. Just a light malty beer.
A plenty fine malty lightly sweet biscuity bready red ale with no detectable hop presence. Very solid.
Tap at Pork & Pickle at MCI. Light brown with minimal head. Malty, light mineral water, bread and a slight grassiness. Taste is mild and bready. Medium body with a fizzy feel.
seems like perhaps an oldish bottle, though I dont see a date. Still has odd hoppy notes for the style, though - I expect bread and toffee and get lightly bitter and herbal hops. Meh.

12oz bottle, courtesy of gregwilsonstl, pours with a clear amber to ruby red body that supports a full tan head of foam. The aroma offers up malts, earthy malts, a hit of caramel malts, floral hops, raisins and brown sugar dusted dates. The taste starts smooth with a pleasing blend of soft sweet malts, faint caramel malts, chocolate malts and roasted malts. Toward midway it picks up sweet fruity ester notes that are lined with dates and raisins. This stays soft and supple right into the finish where a subtle earthy mineral sensation joins in to close out the experience. Nice beer. I dig it.

Tap - fair size foamy head, beautiful dark Amber color, caramel malty aroma and flavor, mild earthy hop balance, pretty good overall 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours clear copper with a fluffy off-white head. Aroma is caramel malts, some grass, hops. Taste follows suit with huge malts and a dry grassy bitterness on the tongue. Finish is a bit too hoppy for the style, and mouthfeel is a little too dense. Outside of the style restrictions, this is a solid ale.

Draught. Pours a slightly hazy reddish dark amber color with a moderate pillowy tan head on there. Nose has some grass and light grains, with hints of toasty caramel coming through. Taste is slightly sweet up front, but has a nice substantivealt backbone with caramel and toast to it.

Bottle. Nose has herbal-spicy hop aroma, some maris-like UK malt notes - these always taste like musty caramel to me. Flavor is malt forward - great textured and relatively complex graininess, light notes of toasted bread, some mild berry-like sweetness, finishes with a modicum of bitterness and mildly floral hops. Pretty good - similiar to an ESB with a little less earthiness.

Translucent copper hue. Minimal sized head with little retention. Relatively stunted malt, caramel, and roast aroma. Significantly better taste. Smooth and creamy texture complimented with flavours of malt, caramel, roast, mild scotch, and a slightly hoppy finish.

I have mixed feelings on this beer. It is excellent in a few ways: body is thick and rich, flavors are fruit and malt, nose is minimal but enticing. There isnt much that makes this beer sing though. Its pretty one level. Not the most drinkable but fairly refreshing.

Bottle.

A- Caramel, subtle spice, malty.

A- Dark amber color, hazy liquid, off white head.

T- Caramel, spices, malty, alcohol burn.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, sharp finish.

O- Decided to pop this open for St. Patricks day since it was the only "Irish" beer I had to go with dinner. This was a mistake. Strong alcohol burn and not much flavor other than some caramel and spice. Just plain awful.

Tap at The Jeffrey. You know you have a stats addiction when there is far better beers to fill my flight with but I need more Irish Ale ticks so go with this instead. Pours reddish. Nose is caramel and malt. Tastes malty, of caramel, lightearthy bitters, red fruit, and toast. Slick palate.
pours a clear amber color with white head. Well balanced and only slightly watery
Reddish yes very lean amber bock like...a good beer but average and sub for this brewery. Appeals to masses I guess no bad funk going on so above average then I digress.

From a bottle... Pours a dark amber with a creamy head. Nice carbonation and lacing. The aroma is a sweet roasted caramel with a piney backbone. Taste is sweet, with slight hops and roasted coffee. Finish is clean. An enjoyable beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nice red body with a creamy head. Nice carbonation and lacing. The aroma is a sweet, roasted caramel and coffee. Taste is sweet, with slight hops and toffee. Finish is clean, easy to drink and recommended.
355ml bottle. Amber pour, very light roastiness which keeps it distint but overall like most in this style its boring.

bottle. hazy dark red with a creamy, long lasting, beige head. fruity, malty aroma but with a hint of tartness. notes of roasted malt and fruity yeast. a hint of oddly placed tartness. medium bodied and creamy. chalky finish from roasted malt.

Bottle to snifter. sweet honey and toffee malt nose and not much else. Pours a dark red with a small off white head. Slightly buttery as it warms. Taste is sweet toffee and caramel up front with little to no bitterness. Slightly sweet finish and missing any slight roasted character that I like in these that lends a drying finish. Really not here with this one. Overall, so so, some roast as it warms, but still finishes too sweet.
A pretty decent red/amber color on this one, with fairly white head. Caramel, bread, and cereal on the nose, follow onto the palate. Finishes with some grass and pine notes to give complexity.

Boulevard Irish Ale is an impressive, flavorful offering. The spices are solid and build the character of the beer. It goes great with food such as beef and smoked meats. It's just as enjoyable on its own. Pour it into a frosted glass!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from 12 oz bottle into pint glass.

Appearance: a thick fluffy off white head recedes at a glacial pace with some fine lacing. Color is a somewhat cloudy reddish amber with plenty of yeast in suspension. Very little streaming carbonation.

Aroma: bready malts dominate the aroma, with some caramel sweetness, a bit of fruit, and some pungent hops.

Mouthfeel: medium bodied, fluffy, and sticky with a somewhat wet finish.

Flavor: toasted bread crust, raisins, caramel, a bit of grassiness, and a strong, lingering hop bitterness in the middle and finish.

Overall: this is an above average, but not outstanding, offering.
I dont really like this kind of beer, but if you like Irish Ales then Id recommend trying it.

Reddish/chestnut brown color with a tan head, nice malty nose. Robust earthy flavors. Really delicious beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Warner Robins, Ga - Lazy Dog Growler - 12 oz bottle. Dark copper appearance, slightly off-white head, thin lacing. Very faint earthy aroma, not unpleasant. Overall a very restrained flavor. Slight maltiness with some caramel notes. Slight bitter hoppines cuts in underneath to keep the interest level going. Stays strong throughout. Overall, decent.

Draft to pint. Looks good for the style; a transparent reddish brown (amber) with foamy off-white head. Smells of malt and biscuit with a touch of caramel sweetness. Tastes like it smells, but more robust, and with a touch of hops. Pleasant on the palate. A good example of the style.

Via trade with RobertDale. The aroma iscaramel, flowers. The appearance is hazy amber, off-white head. The flavor is caramel, floral, earthy, slightly bready. The finish is floral, noble hops, spicy. Medium in body. Decent.
English Pint. Very mild odor of malts. Dark brown cloudy beer with lots of carbonation but minimal head. The malts and spices blend together nicely but the alcohol taste finish is unappealing.

Rated on 5-12-2010 (Bottle) This bottled beer pours a small very, very fizzy head with a short retention, transparent orange body, fast rising carbonation, and spotty amounts of lacing. The aroma is caramel malt, toasty, yeasty, hoppy, and spicy. The taste is sweet, caramel malt, yeasty, wheat, spicy, and lightly hoppy. The palate is spritzy and this beer is medium bodied. Overall, this beer is very easy to drink and while the flavor is not bad tasting, it just did not leave me wanting this beer again.
12 oz bottle. Pours a clear red/copper, with a big off-white head that lasts and leaves fair lacing. Nose is pale malts. Taste is of pale malt, with a mildly bitter hop finish. Kind of watery.
amber color with a thin off-white head. Aroma is bread and toffee. Flavor is bread, toast, toffee, and leather. medium carbonation.

Brown-reddish pour with a thin, creamy tan head. Aroma is of bisquit with sweet, malty overtones. Flavor is of toasted malts, caramel with a lingering, malty and slightly bitter finish. Body is nice and creamy.Definitely does taste "Irish".

I had this at Global Brew. Pours reddish with a off white head. Taste Carmel, sweet, bready. I thought this was good. I would drink this again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a clean and soft ruby/reddish color with a few fingers of crackling tan head. Nose shows some earthy and bready malt with a nice round sweetness and dextrinous notes. Very round and easy flavor, earthy and toasted malt sweetness with a light herbal hop character. Caramel and toffee tones show as well.
pours a dark amber color with a medium sized white head. the aroma is caramel and toffee and the taste is very similar.

An Irish Ale for the Midwest? Great idea! Boulevard has expertly recreated the characteristics of this style. Everything from the red color to the creamy taste seems authentic. The malt flavor is complex and toasty. While many of the common Irish imports seem overly sweet, Boulevard has struck a lovely balance with the hops and malt varieties. To hell with cliches, its a delicious choice for St. Patricks day.

Best by 01MAY12

pours a rusty brown with a quilt of light latte foam and excellent clarity. Spotty lace. Nose is of floral malts and a little bit of caramel. Some tea like, earthy hops. Metallic flavor over a decent amount of sweet malts. There is a certain dry, tart character Im not really digging. Medium bodied with moderately hi carb and a good dry finish. This is okay, nothing more.

Serving type: bottle

03-07-2012

Pour out of 12 oz bottle, clear red pour with thin white head, aroma brought notes of toasted malts, some bready, biscuit notes going into caramel, toffee, nice yeasty and spicy notes in there. Taste is a mix of caramel, toffee, and some bread, hints of toast, yeast, into slight grass, touch of fruity notes as well, finishing slightly spicy, sweet.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2013 Dark reddish amber color. 2 finger tan head. Malts and molasses on the nose. Malty caramel taste. Medium mouth feel. Actually a quite tasty beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This is a decent beer though not a fan of the style. Had this at a hamburger joint in Kansas City. Good beer.
Pours a lovely copper color. Aroma of caramel and bread. Nice toasty flavor with caramel malt and a dry finish.
Just a solid Irish ale that you can knock back and enjoy time and time again. I found it paired very nice with poultry dishes and fresh veggies. Enjoy!
Pours copper with a moderate head. Smells and tastes of spicy hops with a toasty malt flavor. Finishes dry and bitter.

12 oz. bottle poured to a Czech-pils glass with a fairly clear, copper color, off white/light tan frothy head foam that turned cakey, and wavy cling to the lacing. The nose was lightly toasted, caramel, sweetness, and actually some orange and peach notes. The flavor presented medium, lingering and well rounded hop bitterness, malt to match, and a touch of toffee. Medium bodied, decently carbonated, and nicely drinkable

Big light Brown head. Dark brown red body. Aroma of roast malts, honey. Flavor of the toasty Irish red to start but then it transfers to a piney reisinous hoppy American red. Body is also very light for style which is somewhat pleasant.

Bottle. Pours a a deep amber with lots of light tan head. Great retention and a some thin lacing, looks very inviting. Aroma is sweet malt, bread, yeast, caramel/toffee. Flavor is fruity, strong apple, with a malty, nutty, caramel finish. Moderate carbonation, medium-light body, and crisp texture. Super drinkable, light, tasty, fruity, mildly malty ale, pretty tasty. One of the better irish ales Ive had.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours a solid red color with a decent head of loose, off white bubbles.  The nose is a mix of bread and malt with a touch of earthiness.  The flavor highlights the malt with a little sweetness, slight toasted notes, and a little bit of nuttiness.  Smooth on the tongue with a dry finish that has a touch of bitterness.  Medium bodied with lower carbonation.  A solid session beer for malt fans.  I found this one rather enjoyable.

This was like a light Scottish ale for me. Ive had this numerous times and it doesnt overly impress. It may just be that the style lacks something. Malty sweet aroma and a brown, tea-colored presence with a medium fizzy head. Medium weight palate with average carbonation. Light malty taste with some sweet and maybe a little hops presence on the finish. The beer is not bad, just average.

Very little aroma but a nice malty sessionable beer...nice caramel ly flavor with a very easy drinking presence... I long for potatoes and river dance!...

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a dark reddish amber with a large tan head and some lacing.  Aroma is brown sugar and caramel.  Taste is malty and sweet with caramel ans spices.
Im not sure what there is to enjoy about this beer, it had no taste and finished super dry, so maybe thats it, it looks good.. nice dark ruby but not a real tasty beer.
red brown in appearance. sweet caramel malt. wonderfully smooth in full bodied beer one of the best Ive had

12 oz bottle pours amber with a off white head.  Aroma of nuts, caramel malts and a little spice.  Taste is caramel malts, chocolate and spice/pepper finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours brown with hints of red. Aroma is earthy and hay. taste follows nose with some toffee. This one surprised me. Very good
UPDATED: JUL 25, 2016 Thanks Uncle Dave. Nice balanced all around beer. Dry finish. A little light in the mellow roasted flavor for an Irish ale but still pretty good stuff. Serving: Bottle

Aroma of nutty malts and...tomato sauce.  Well, that is different for a beer.  Good billowy head; lesser lacing.  Tastes like nutty malts, maybe a hint of cocoa, and...a little bit of tomato sauce again in the finish.  My bottle was fresh and cold, so I cant blame such an unexpected aroma and flavor on dating or temp.  An interesting little beer.  I will say that the tomato sauce flavors and aromas DO lessen once this sits for a few minutes after the pour...but it is definitely there to start.  How odd.  Becomes more toasty upon sitting.
On tap at 1839 Taphouse in Columbia. Pours a reddish color with white head. Caramel, malty, dusty flavors. Not bad for an irish.
My kind of Irish Ale. Nice dark red pour with an off white head. Great malt complexity with a nice hop profile of a little stickiness that tapers off.

I have drank this beer a lot over my years in Kansas.  Rating this particular 12oz bottle that I poured into a Lost Abbey cool long stem glass.  The beer poured with an amazing, voluminous head.  The head is slightly khaki in color and leaves a thick lacing as it settles in.  Color of the beer is dark ruby with brown tints.  Medium clarity in the beer.  In the aroma I am first hit with a fruit ester akin to spoiled fruits.  After that is earthy dry dark malts.  Flavor is stronger on the earthy malts and a touch of fruity hops (more than I want but that is the state of beers nowadays).  Finishes and fruity.  I think this a fruitier batch than usual but still a good, non-boring take on the style.

text: 12 oz bottle poured into my Guinness 2010 World Cup glass.  Dark reddish-brown and hazy with a big off-white head that slowly settles.  The aroma and flavor is toasted malts, sweet caramel, toffee and light roast.  Mild bitter hops balance things out.  Medium body with a lightly sweet finish.
Poured a cloudy amber color with an off white head. Aroma is caramel, bread, cereal, raisins, with a hint of citrus. Taste is raisin, chocolate, caramel, and citrus with a tangy sweet aftertaste.

I had this on tap in KC. I bought a 6 pack when I got home. Tap was much better. It is still one of the better Irish Reds. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Deep ruby brown color with minimal cream head. Not a strong scent, some brown sugar, caramel malt. Taste is also too subtle, a little caramel malt and some pepper like bite towards the end. Overall a pretty bland beer, appearance is its only real strong suit. Ok as a session beer, but not even my first choice there. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap at Tapwerks St. Patricks celebration. Pours a deep red with a grayish brown head that dissipates slowly to the edges. Aroma has a nice note of grain and bread with touches of grass hops and toast. Flavor is similar starting with bread and then is joined by a nice light grass note with a hint of toast.

Bottle from a Build-Your-Own-Sixer from Binnys. Pours a deep, dark coppery amber, with a medium, slightly off-white head, okay retention with excellent lacing. Nose is malty and some grass. Mouth is bready, malty, some caramel with a bitterness on the fadeway. Nice Irish Red. Would go well with a big pile of fries (or chips, or whatever they callem in Dublin).
Draft. Copper pour, small off-white head. Aroma of grain, light herbal/grassy hops, toast, toffee. Taste is malty, cereal grains herbal, toast, grass. Palate is soft, creamy, sweet finish.

Pours a reddish copper that is near brown with slightly rocky foam that lingers. The smell is a little fruity yeast flavor with the roasted slightly sweet grains. The flavor is earthy and grainy with toasted bread and a semi toffee tone coming out. The minimal hops give a little herbal earthy bump to the earthy grains and hearty filling carbonation. The finish does have a touch of fruits in it but they are over run by a nutty toffee earthy grain. Slight buttery feel, nice take in the style, preferred over several others in the Irish and Scottish ale of similar build, a focused straight ahead brew.

The color is a reddish brown with an off-white head that disappears quickly, and the aroma is strongly dough/yeast with minor hints of roasted malts. The taste is mildly umami, slightly sweet, slightly salty, and slightly sour; furthermore, the palate combines a medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, and an abrupt finish to round out this beer.
Bottle. Light caramel, tea malt, and dusty aroma. Hazy copper / amber with a moderate beige head. Toast, caramel, and herbal hops flavor. Medium body and carbonation.  Tastes like a hoppy amber.

Pours a deep reddish amber, with lots of thick foamy tan colored head on top. Leaving some mild lacing. 

Aroma is full of malts. Caramel. Some mild hops are in the back ground. Smells kind of sweet.

Tastes of sweet malts. Follows the scent profile well. Some very mild bitterness at the end. Mildly dry finish. 

Mouthfeel is medium body, with out a lot of carbonation.

Purchased from Metcalf Discount Liquor in Olathe, KS.  Poured from a 12 oz. bottle with a "best by" date of 5/1/13 into an English pint glass.  Pours dark amber/orange with a 3/4" off-white frothy head; some lacing.  Head quickly diminishes, but never leaves completely due to soft but constant carbonation, similar to a champagne.  Once in the glass, it exhibits a moderate hoppy aroma of flowers and citrus.  Very slight earthy yeasty component.  Beer remains slightly cloudy with very tiny particles.  Taste is a mix between sweet and bitter, but both very light.  However, it finishes sweeter with an average duration and a bit of a metallic feel.  It has a light to medium body with a slight oily texture.

It has a malty, roasty aroma. Color was a dark brown and not opaque. The taste was light and rather thin in body with a malty, lightly carbonated  taste and feel. This beer is average....I would consider it a step down from a good ol fashioned Guinness.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2013 From bottle. Pours a rather dark amber with a nice off-white head.  Toasted malt and maybe some dark fruit in the nose.  Some sweetness in the taste with a surprisingly nice hop kick.  Mildly medicinal finish.  A pleasant spring ritual.

Mildly hazy amber pour. Light off white head. Decent lacing. Floral/citrusy hop aroma. Mild roasty malt aroma. Malt sweetness comes through first. Toasty caramel/toffee. Lingering citrusy hop flavor. ---Rated via iPhone

Good beer.  Enough flavor to be interesting.  Toasty and malt taste.  (3.5/5 in other app.)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a mostly translucent reddish amber with a medium bubbly off white head.  Aroma of toffee, toasted malt and cherries.  Flavor of roasted nuts, toffee and dried cherries.

Surprising how highly rated this beer is.  Compare this to amber ales and its pretty good. Caramel flavor dominates with some bread dough.  Not much in the way of aroma, sadly.  Middle of the road as far as Boulevard goes.

12 oz bottle, best by 5/12.  Cloudy brown with a beige skin.  Nose is scotch, red licorice and walnut.  Fizzy medium body with a dry bite.  Taste is unripe strawberry, lemon pith, earthy citrus and tobacco.  Great balance and eminently drinkable.  Nice Irish ale.

Had on tap at Wild Monk, a new gastro pub in downtown Lagrange. Served in a Two Brothers pint glass.

A: Pours a dark mahogany with a thin white head forming on the pour. A thin white film is left on the top of the brew and it leaves some sticky sheets of lace.

S: Very malt forward nose. Sweet and pale malts with some raw bread dough and some caramel. Slight earthy pine in the background.

T: Caramel and pale malts up front with some doughy bread, a touch of peat and some some bitter hops on the finish.

M: Medium bodied with a medium carbonation. Nice sweet maltiness is left on the palate.

O: A solid Irish red. Nice malty flavors with a subtle hop finish. Not overly complex, but easily drinkable.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 03-18-2012

bottle - Pours light hazy amber-red with a one finger off-white head. Theres a mild, indistinct malt aroma. It tastes sweet with toasted caramel malt, a light to medium body, and some slight bitterness in the finish. The malt is very much at the forefront as expected for the style. Okay.

to be fair - bottle said best before 5/15 - dont think affected my rating; beer had a nice brown suger and caramel aroma.  Taste was that but bland after first flavors - maybe I was spolied byt the ipas over the weekend but this beer needed more flavor on back end...
Deep ruddish color. Bit tan head. Nice malty, fresh bread, yeasty nose. Clean malts and yeast but overly done. Crisp finish. Yumm.

Not a big fan of the reds and i got a hold of this one from a friend he said i would like it and by golly he was right.  I purchased 4, 6 packs... Never know when ill find it again.  Thank you boulevard for your great work.

It pours a dark ruby red with a thick tan head that slowly fades. Not getting really anything from the aroma.  Its medium bodied but not all that flavorful. Possibly some chocolate notes upfront with a little bit of bitterness at the finish. Ok

Originally reviewed: 4/21/09. Bottle courtesy of monsterfat (BA) in a recent trade.

Pours a ruby red with a good-sized two-finger white head on it. Retention is strong, but the lacing is weak. Some sticky globs, but not much. Smells of bananas, apples, sugar cane, and bread. 

Mouthfeel is crisp due to a medium/high amount of carbonation. Flavor is pretty muted and tame. A very malty brew. Definite caramel malty goodness. Bitterness is really low. This is a very drinkable beer. Low ABV + mild sweetness = high drinkability. Recommend.

Pours a brown, translucent color with fizzy head that quickly dissipates leaving no lacing. Caramel and toasted malt with a slight hint of chocolate and coffee.  Medium sweetness in the aroma, but primarily a medium bitter taste on the tongue. Mild doughy and earthy yeast flavors. Lively carbonation, sticky palate and medium bodied. Medium bitter finish.  Very drinkable.

Dark Brown with abundant haze. The beer gives off an aroma of yeasts, caramel, cocoa, barley, and malts. While the flavor itseld consists of yeasts, barley and malts. Simple tasting but the flavors that are present are good. Its heavier in body and theres a slight thickness to it, but the low carbonation helps make this easy to drink. 

This is a beer that doesnt take any risks and plays it safe, and it does that very well. Its a simple tasting beer, but a good simple tasting beer, although I wouldve loved to have seen the flavor match the complexity of the smell

poured from bottle into a pint glass. Pours a dark amber color with a nice head

Well balanced with very good aromas of toffee, caramel, grains, a touch of hops and bits of citrus.

Nice medium body with a good feel. Nice flavors of toffee, caramel and some citrus but lacking a bit on the mid

A very drinkable irish ale. Yet another beer from boulevard that Ive enjoyed and want again

Bottle.  Pours a caramel color with a fluffy yellow head that dissipates quickly.  Scent is very malty and toasty with loads of caramel and a hint of hop.  Taste is big malt, biscuits, with a nice balance of hops and lingering bitterness.
Hands down an all time favorite from Boulevard.  Consistently perfect from year to year... perfect blend of caramel/bread malt and citrus hops.  Exceptionally good on tap.

pours dark copper, almost mahogany, with a large, fluffy off-white head. Smells malty, sweet biscuits and butter, with hints of bitter hops. Tastes sweet, but balanced with some bitterness from hops. Medium-bodied with a smooth texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Boulevard Irish Ale finishes with a nice biscuit sweetness.
Sweet, malty, tasty, and pretty damn drinkable.  I am really beginning to love this brewery more and more

I had this beer on tap at Bigelos Bistro in downtown Edwardsville,IL. It Pretty good. Not a very strong aroma or taste though they are both good.

Dark red.  No head.  Good caramelization.  Medium Ibus.  Like a dark killians....  "hell I dont know" -jimp
Pours tarnished bronze with thick white head. Nose is toasty with a bit of soap.  Nicely thick on the tongue with biscuity and toasted malts, bread and subtle raisin.  Nice beer.

Really nice soft amber color, frothy head to start (wheat assisted?).  nice roasted grain aroma.  Medium sweetness with a low hop bitterness.  Sticks to the tongue ever so slightly as it passes.  I think it has a larger alcohol profile than most Irish ales, but a really pleasant amber brew.
Cloudy red amber. thin tan head.  Scent is malt, bread, toffee.  Flavour is caramel, roasted, very smooth and creamy, sweet breads....tasty.

Nice deep amber color which is short on head. Nice balance sweet and bitter tastes. Very satisfying. Would drink again.

Pours a clear deep copper with a 1 finger head and ok retention.  Aroma is toffee, red fruit, maris otter floor malt, sweet caramel.  Taste is sweet biscuit, toasted bread, and some yeast-derived fruitiness.  Body is light, low carbonation, very sweet yet with a somewhat balanced finish.  Overall, not anything special.

Dark red with nice head. Little lacing but overall a very nice appearance. Very light  malty aroma. Nice roasted malt taste with hint of caramel. Well balanced with slight hop bitterness at the finish.

12oz bottle from Picks poured into an English Pint. Pours a lightly cloudy dark amber with a half finger of off-white head. Aroma of light caramel and lots of bready malt. Taste is light bitter and light sweet. Bread and caramel with a little bit of hops in there. Medium bodied with a thin yet creamy texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish. Overall, very good. Its worth getting the whole 6pack.

This is an good beer.  Poured with a huge head.  Aroma is of fruity soap and metal.  I taste pine nuts and bread. This beer doesnt do much for me.

Id call this an American amber, probably. It is a nice brown color w/ a long-lasting head of fine white bubbles. The nose is mostly toasty malts and a pleasingly firm malt bitterness in the finish. Its a full bodied beer but not heavy and very drinkable. One of those brews that makes  me wish it was a little lower alcohol so I could drink more of it.
On tap in KC. Average beer, average everything else too. The whole world is average. Rated.
Dark amber pour.   Good malty flavor with a hint of bitterness; some light caramel behind both.  Good.

Cloudy ruby pour - moderate, soapy, lasting lace - nose and flavor are quite toasty and biscuity - the flavor is medium dry, with a lasting biscuit crispness throughout, but with a mild undercurrent of sweetness, esters, plum and raisin - creamy, full mouthfeel - this is quite nice, wit a complexity you do not normally see in beers like this - very nice.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Colonial Wine and Spirits, 1/23/12


Aroma: The nose has some sweet and dry caramel notes, roasted malts, bread, and yeast

Appearance: It pours a clear, dark, caramel-orange color with a foamy beige head and medium lace

Flavor: Light-medium sweet, caramel and bready malts, balanced by a light earthy/dry caramel bitterness

Palate: Its light-medium, with a somewhat smooth, fairly drinkable mouthfeel, and a slightly dry finish

Overall Impression: 
I thought this was a decent Amber/Irish Ale.  It has a solid combination of flavors that are pretty much on target for the style.  It isnt any kind of crazy beer, just a solid and drinkable offering.
A nice red/amber color with a foamy tan head and some lacing.  It has a pleasant malty aroma with a great malt flavor thats not too sweet and leaves a great aftertaste.
It was lighter-bodied than I thought it would be and had a good-grainy taste. Slightly bitter at the end with a bit of an alcohol presence in the flavor.

Its a beautiful amber-red with a great head that lasts, slowly dissipating into a nice sheen with fine but beautiful sheets of lacing.   Crisp and clean is the smell of this beer.  Toasty and hoppy.  A great malt character, almost like the pristine frozen woods of the northern states, permeates your taste buds when youre taking in the great beery goodness of this lovely creation. Yet theres still plenty of hoppiness, penetrating the frozen tundra, reminding you that summers on its way.   Quite smooth, low bitterness on the finish, nice carbonation and medium body.   A very tasty Irish red, great value too.  One of Boulevards better seasonals.

12 oz bottle.  Bright reddish crimsom with a thick, frothy off white head.  Mild hops in the nose, light cereal and red fruit.  Flavor is nice, toasty, mild fruit, light leafy hop presence towards the back end.  Caramel and biscuit malts, mild sweetness.  Pretty easy ale to get into.  Not all that complex, but certainly nice and drinkable.  Full bodied.  Finishes with leafy hops.  Another competent ale from Boulevard.

First rating for me, so forgive any naivety. Pours a decent red, but Ive seen better in brews like Great Divide Hoss. Aroma is ripe with barley and wheat. The mouthfeel is a bit too sharp with carbonation, but is still enjoyable. The taste is of barley and pine with the expected red ale aftertaste. Overall a decent brew, but not a particularly memorable one.

Beautiful mahogany color, no head.  Rich cereal flavor that stays on the palate.  Toasty almost smokey on the front end.  Thin mouth feel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a reddish brown with 1 finger of tan head and moderate lacing. Aroma is roasted malts, caramel, cherries, and a hint of sherry and ash. Flavor is his brew poured up a dark copper-colored body with a hearty tan-colored head with good retention and minimal lacing. Flavor is caramelized malts, dark fruits, spices, hops. Lots of carbonation and thin to moderate body give it a decent mouthfeel. Solid offering.

Tasted from bottle into nucleated pint glass. Poured a hazy reddish-brown color with creamy off-white head, somewhat lasting with a little lace. Aromas of bread, toast, roasted barley and some nice earthy, woodsy finishing hops. Very complex malt-sweetness balanced by flavorful hops bitterness, notes of biscuits, crackers, caramel, apricot. Hoppier than true-to-style Irish Ales, but it works as an enhancement. Boulevard Irish Ale still retains the characteristic color, body, roastiness, dryness and ever-so-slightly fruity Irish ale yeast profile. Extremely tasty.

This brew poured up a dark copper-colored body with a hearty tan-colored head with good retention and minimal lacing. Aromas of caramel, toasted malts/oats, bread (or biscuits?). Flavors are very well balanced of sweet malts, toasted oats, dark fruits (plums), and light alcohol taste near the finish. Medium-bodied with a very dry finish with a lingering sweet, malty taste.

Appearance: clear garnets and ambers under an off-white head  solid collar and decent blanket. Swirls creamy, no lace.

Nose: candied sugars, maraschino cherries. Taffy toffee crunch bars. Pineapple. Figs and dates. Raw brown sugar granules, natural sugar, and cinnamon sticks.

Palate: chocolate and cinnamon sticks in the back. Dry finis with melba toast, pumpernickel sticks, apple skins, and tobacco. Hard hit of sweet maraschino cherries in the middle. Cooked brown sugar, cane sugar, and toffee crunchies. Dried leaves, twigs, and sticks. Figs and dates along the sides. Apple skins. Never too sweet or cloying, crisp and clean.

Final Thoughts: very tasty and intriguing and I liked it. Far more complexity than I was expecting, though the chocolate was an unexpected addition. A solid offering from Boulevard Brewing.
Brownish pour with frothy tan head and lace. Light resiny hops and sweet caramel arooma. Sweet caramel and earthy hop flavor. Medium bodied but foamy.

Bottle pours deep amber(hint of red) with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet and malty with light notes of caramel, and some earthy hops. Flavor shows the same with additional notes of red berry, nuts, and a hint of peat. Almost seamed like a really light scotch ale. Wasnt too complicated and went down easy.

12oz bottle-had with stevo after a hike to a vortex in Sedona-pours a foamy light tan head and amber color.  Aroma is light/medium malt-cereal/bread, some earthy/herbal hops, yeast.  Taste is light/medium malt-cereal/bread, some earthy/herbal hops, yeast.  Slight drying at finish.
12oz bottle at home.  Super tasty but maybe a little sweet for the style but honestly who cares? It was well done and fun to drink.

Bottle served in an English pint. Pours dark amber in color with an orange-white head that fills half the glass. Good retention and excellent lace. The nose is bright, like a grassy-hopped heavy vienna with toast and candy malt. Light sweet, light bitter. Medium body, and well balanced, with dry malts on the attack followed with a light, long bitter finish. More hoppy than any Irish Ales Ive tried.

12 oz. brown bottle. A dark red almost brown beer with a 2" head. The aroma is slightly sweet and fruity. The taste has caramel, actually a good amount of it. This is an easy drinking beer and quite boring actually. What the heck is an Irish ale by the way?
Clear deep amber red with a fizzy off white head. Sweet caramel and mild hops profile to the aroma and taste with a clean finish.

On tap.
Dark amber pour with very little head.  Caramel and bready malt aromas - slightly sweet with more caramel malt flavor.  Very drinkable but also very forgettable.
Super dark red color with a small tan head. Has a nice roasty taste that is rather smooth.

bottle.  Pours dark, slightly murky red brown with fizzy grey head.  Mild aroma of toast, caramel.  Medium bodied, with a very chalky mouthfeel, and a dry finish.  Surprised by a high amount of carbonation here.  Flavor of dry, grassy hops with some roasted brown malt, as it gets warms a subtle caramel / toffee sweetness.  I was blown away by every boulevard smokestack series but have yet to be impressed really with any of there mainline beers.  Still a decent ale, not sorry to be drinking it.
great for the style but not my favorite. bread, caramel, roasty, herbs, earthy, amber, hazy, frothy, lightly bitter, medium body, slick feel, lively,
12oz bottle in Chicago. Smooth, dry bitter. Not too spicy malting, a touch of alc on the body is good. Nice enough.
Nice red pour with a creamy whitish head.  Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, honey and very very light hops. Flavor is mostly malt, some honey notes, alcohol, fruit and almonds.
Poured redish maple in color.  Nose had very little except roasted barley.  Taste was ok with toasted malts and a little toffee.  Drinkable but not something special.

12 oz bottle. Clear red/amber with a thick beige head. Aroma of biscuit dough, caramel and a light herbal quality. Flavor is lots of bready and caramel malt with a very light hop bitterness. Medium body with average carbonation and a smooth mouth feel. Great Irish Ale, lots of flavor and very drinkable.
Bottle .  Red pour with lasting off white head.  Rich aroma of caramel.  Toasty flavor, whough with something slightly off putting in the finish.  Still, more good than bad in this ale.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Bottle @ home. Reddish maroon appearance with a tan head. Sweet, slightly roasty caramel malty with a light hoppy nose with some alcohol. Sweet nutty, caramel malty. Amber malty, slightly nutty finish.

Bottle; Pour is Copper with amber highlights - Off white head that retains fairly well. Aroma is fruitier than I was expecting - with a toasty malt profile as well. A toasty, toffee flavor profile, with a Hop bitterness present, but perhaps more so than I would like for the style when comparing the malt side. Either way, this is a nice attempt at an Irish that I did enjoy.
UPDATED: FEB 5, 2014 A red beer with a tan head.  The aroma is caramel and dough.  The flavor is caramel, roasty malt, and a little bit of anise.

Orange copper in color, pretty clear, with a long lasting off-tan creamy head.  Smells like biscuit-y caramel and loads of pale malts.  Actually smells reminiscent of an amber ale.  Tastes like an amber, too, just with much less hop bitterness.  Im sure hops were used, but there is no bitterness here.  Taste profile has a load of yeasty biscuit, some light caramel, with some cereal grain notes.  Pretty smooth and easy-going, but a little too light for my palate.  Not a bad alternative during St. Pattys, but I wouldnt get it often..
Gorgeous red color. Sweet and bitter at the same time. Well balanced malty and moderately hoppy flavor makes it one Ill definately have again.

It pours sparkling ruby with an average sized off-white head with good lacing. The aroma is average malt, average hops, average yeast with notes of pear and paper. Light bodied with a  thin texture and lively carbonation with an astringent finish. It has average duration, light sweetness, acidity and bitterness.
Very dark beer with a white head.  Tastie with a slight bitter flavor. But a very nice attempt at a irish ale.

Clear mahogany with a moderate off-white head. Aroma of pale and caramel malts, toast, and some grassy hops. The taste is malty sweet with a little bit of finishing hop bitterness. The finish is slightly bitter and bready. The body is medium and smooth. Good.

Bottle, thanks to Phaleslu. Pours hazy ruby amber with a large creamy beige head. Aroma of citrus and floral hops, toffee, vanilla, raisin. Taste is mild but good, malt, sweet fruity esters, very little bitterness on the finish. Medium thick texture, soft carbonation. Really solid beer.
This beer surprised me. Nice peaty, earthy flavors. Very well balanced and full of flavor.
bottle.  from phaleslu.  thanks peter!    doughy sweet caramel.  some light roast.   herbal, grainy, toffee taste.   not bad.

Pours a clear bright garnet color with a sizable off white head that sticks around and coats the glass.  Aroma is sweet malt and dark bread.  Full rick flavor of sweet roasted malt, caramel and unsweetened dark chocolate.  Some hoppy bitterness comes through at the end, but is not overdone.  Very good interpretation.

12. Pours a clear medium brown with garnet edges and a loose tan head that doesnt do much, not for very long. Spotty lace. Big brown bread and brown sugar nose, kind of toasty, very caramelly. Creamy medium body, a little light on the carb. Toast, caramel, brown bread, and brown sugar on the mid-palate. Mild malty finish with a little herbal hop finish. Not a lot of yeast or hop character to this one, and precious little carbonation.

Smell is slightly hoppy and red.  Not much carbonation on this one.  Taste is very pubstyle, with all of the flavors meshing together.  Theres some hop notes, theres some yeast in there, theres some red notes.  Kind of tastes like a home brew.  Not bad really, but nothing unique or fresh tasting about it.

12oz. Bottle:  Got in trade from phaleslu; THANKS Peter!  Aroma of malt, slight caramel, light toasting, and some bread and cereal.  Poured orange in color with a medium-sized, creamy, tan head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Slightly cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout.  Very good lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet.  Tastes of malt, caramel, and a little bit of hops.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt and caramel finish.

Bottle.  Malty and toasted aroma, same with the taste.  Taste of toffee, coffee and chocolate.  A bit of carbonation to it, and a nice aftertaste.  This is a surprisingly good beer, wasnt expecting it to be this tasty - shows what happens when you doubt Boulevard. 5.8% alcohol.

Pours amber into the glass with a white head.  Aroma is malty with a slight tinge of roast.  Flavor is a really nice balance between caramel and biscuity malts and hop bitterness to balance it out.  For a style that Im not really fond of I really enjoyed this brew.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a slightly cloudy amber with a nice biege head.  Aroma of malt and caramel.  Taste is somewhat sweet, malt and caramel nicely balanced with hops.  Some bitterness in the finish.  Nice session beer.

12 oz. bottle from HyVee Marion

Ar:  Toasted nuts, a bit of toffee, and some 
Ap: Pours a hazy reddish brown with a 1" light cinnamon head that dissipates pretty quickly, but leaves decent lace.
T: Nutty malt sweetness up front.  Rounded out with nice hop bitterness.  Sweet but not overly so.
P: Rich, somewhat thick body with pretty strong carbonation.  Chewy but still not overly filing.

O:  Top notch.  Glad I grabbed a a boulevard sampler for the superbowl.
Among the best Irish Reds Ive had.  Good caramel flavor and almost perfect session beer.

Bottle: Pours a nice copper red color with a light head. Nose of roasted barley, caramel and some rich light nutty sweet malts. The flavor is balanced, noticeable chocolate with a darker roast profile. Nice sweet hop notes in the flavor and a chewy body. Very nice and delicious for an irish red.

12 oz. bottle from Wine and Cheese Place. This is the lone bottled Boulevard beer that has eluded me thus far (Imperial Stout being the only other one I have and havent rated), so its nice to see a fresh 2011 batch come out. Pours a clear, rich ruby-amber color with a finger-thick off-white head that leaves some uneven lacing. Aroma of toast, roasted barley malts, nuts, earthy hops, some fruits- a nice, simple and traditional aroma for this style. Flavor of roasted barley malts, toast, earthy hops, overripe pit fruits, berries, wet leaves, and dry grains. Light-medium bodied, with medium carbonation and a toasty, earthy mouthfeel. Pretty nice beer, a good sipper without much fuss.

A red pour with a rocky, tan head.  It has a sweet malt aroma with notes of toffee and nuts.  The medium body has a slick texture.  The taste is somewhat roasted with some bitterness toward the finish.

Loose bottle, $1.50 @ HyVee Storm Lake. "Best By 06/21/10." Oops. Well, I had a Bully! Porter that lagered just wonderfully in a fridge for two years, so heres hoping: Pours a robust head in my glass, above a darkish red ale with tiny bits of grain or yeast sediment floating around. Smell is fine, a nice caramel roast malt that may or may not have subsided in strength, but did not go off. Im sticking my thumb up for its taste, too. A robust kind of caramel malt again, just a little bit sticky Alcohol is probably a touch higher than the stated abv what with the secondary ferment; it certainly is noticeable here. I thought I caught a touch of unmalted wheat here, and sure enough, the label has it in the ingredients. Rough grain finish, but very entertaining. Im much enjoying Boulevards regular beers, I just sometime to have access to some of their specialty beers.

Appearance:

This Irish ale pours a dark amber almost to the point of being light brown. Pouring it from a bottle into a pint glass generated little to no head, maybe about half a finger of an off white cream colored head. There is very little carbonation and no yeast sediment which surpised me since it is a bottle conditioned beer.

Aroma:

The nose is dominated by malt. It smelled like caramel, raisin, and has a few notes that remind me of a bock. I am picking up a little toastiness too, It is quite nice.

Taste:

The taste is good. You get subtle malts and hops playing together quite nicely. The hop characteristics really give the beer a good bitter touch to the end of the sweet malts you get up front. And they dont dance away, they really stick to your tongue for a long finish.

Palate:

Light to Medium body that will develop a nice head in your mouth when you swish the beer around.

Overall:

The beer is enjoyable, but doesnt stand out as anything amazing. It is a middle of the road Irish Ale. I would prefer it over Killians any time it was presented, but wouldnt drink it on a daily basis.

Dark amber pour from bottle.  Large, lasting head.  Aroma is malts, biscuit and some hops.  Taste is lightly bitter, with notes of fruit and nuts.  Smooth finish.  Glad I picked this one up - I will be drinking this again!!
Bottled sample.  Tough to describe this one.  Very malty and almost somoky flavour.  Nicely carbonated.  Might not have this one again though.  Not my style

Bottle- It pours a nice amber color with a good head. The smell is that of grain with a hint of malt. The taste is crisp with a bit of bitterness. The body is light and smooth with a dry finish with a hint of bitterness. Is an enjoyable beer for kicking back.

Bottle.  Pours a clear coppery red color. Thin white head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is buttery caramel, toffee and grassy hopes.  Flavor is caramel malt and plenty of grassy and pine hops.  Medium mouthfeel and a slightly sticky finish.  Much hoppier than a traditional Irish red.  Decent beer, but nothing special.
Nice and toasty hopped up red ale.  Thicker malt action, giving a great blend of malt vs. hop.  Mildly carbonated.  Not bad.
Clear copper color/ khaki head. Mild spicy caramel aromas. smooth medium body.  Good lagered toasty, spicy caramel flavors, nicely bitter finish.

text: This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a very large sized head of finely sized tan colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a softly carbonated transparent copper brown colored body. The mild aroma was malty and dough. The thin mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start mediumly tingly at the finish. The flavor contained notes of metallic hops and malt. An OK brew just nothing special.
Toasty, red, irish ale that fits the bill for the spring season. Nice hop balance on the backside...

Dark red-amber with off white head. Aroma is toasted grain, dried fruits, light spice, fruity hops. Flavor is toasted bread with bitter-sweet jam, brown sugar, spicy and herbal undertones. Finish is balanced with a light to medium body and effervescence. Very drinkable.

Bottle. Medium amber body, clear. Frothy white head, mostly diminishing. The aroma is malty with notes of caramel, bread and toast. Hints of floral hops. A slight vingary note. The flavor is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly bitter and lightly acidic. It finishes lighty sweet, lightly to moderately bitter and lightly tart. Light to medium body, watery texture and lively carbonation. OK, but the vinegar in the aroma and tartness in the finish seemed out of place.
Dark amber, foamy, light tan head.  Smells sweet and of a bit of toast.  Taste of a full flavored honey and hops with a pleasant bitter finish.

Appearance: Pours a dark amber with visible carbonation and a thick frothy head.

Aroma: Light sweet bready malt.

Taste: Burnt toast, molasses and spicy hops.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied with high carbonation.

Overall:  Solid and bold, possibly the best Irish Ale Ive had to date.

aroma is nutty caramel with background of near bracing bitterness.  appearance is well polished cara-gold with lingering head, heavy carb and immediate lacing.  flavor is far more balanced then most of the drivel often found within this style.  lack of expected cloying caramel sludge; crisp sharp hops bring malty sugars under control.

12oz Bottle  Gravity Beer Market  Olympia, WA
Aroma  Big malt with grass and hops aroma.     
Appearance  Light Amber in color, Clear with a thin head.   
Flavor  Nice malt flavors with a good hops addition. Nice earthy flavors.   
Palate    Dry finish with a Nice Mouthfeel. 
Overall  One of the tastier Irish ales.

Out of a 12 ounce bottle.  Nice fairly fine head.  First taste cold was sweet and as the beer warmed tended more towards the malt character.  Good beer with a nice backbone.  Also has a semi yeasty taste which is fairly subdued.
Dark amber with big puffy head. Inviting sweet/floral aroma. Flavor is mild with just a little hops. Feels thin. Its OK.

From a mixed six from the Kroger on Lamar.  Nice reddish orange pour with a little head.  Aroma is dark fruit, brown sugar, and a little fruity hops.  Taste is a malts, and citrus, and caramel.  Nice finish.

Draft. Poured a clear crimson color with a sticky off white head. The aroma was subdued overall with whiffs of candied plum and some brown sugar. Light to medium bodied and delicately sweet. I tasted brown sugar, toffee, and some herbal hops. Easy drinker.
Pours a cloudy, rich red. Aroma is malty with a hint of hops. Flavor is really good, and easy to enjoy. Very much like a pale ale which is what I like over many red ales.

Bottle...  Poured a hazy, reddish with a thin, beige head.  Aroma of toasted almond, sugary, caramel candied malts.  The grain profile is great on this, with a nice light character but also a solid roast thats balanced by hops.  Very complex for the low 5.8%.  I enjoyed this quite a bit and was a welcomed participant during my Saint Patricks day party.

The pour is a slightly hazy, reddish-chestnut color with a moderately full, canvas-colored, fluffy, frothy head which is somewhat lasting and leaves some frothy lace.  The nose is subtle but pleasant; toasted caramel, toasted grains, faint roast, and some earth.  The flavor is similar but not so subtle; toasted caramel, sweet breads, earthy/spicy hops, nice roast undertones, and an anise tinge.  The palate is fitting with a medium body, a nearly lively carbonation, and a clean/round mouthfeel.  The finish is more bitter than most Irish ales with similar earth and spice notes to match grains, and light caramel; almost a rye-like with the earth, spice, and grain notes.  A very balanced Irish ale with nice complementary hop notes which are uncommon in this style.  A nice, drinkable beer with subtle nuances on the tongue and a fitting palate.
Medium, clear borwn.  Sweetish brown ale aroma with an almost pruney tone.  A little astringent.  Strong peat tones. Tap, Flying Saucer, Kansas City.

A march favorite, something to enjoy when youve been surrounded too long by barleywines. On tap at crescent moon, not much head. Slightly sweet nose. Probably a simple beer, but my reality includes peat and gypsum, quite possibly imagined.

Bottle at Flying Saucer, Houston.Pours a deep amber/redwood bark with a nice, thick, off-white head.  Nose is faint bready sweet malt and quiet hops.  Flavor is flat and slightly malted hops.  Average and tingly on the tongue.  Needs more oomph.

text: Draft at boulevard brewpub at K.C. Airport.  Strong caramel aroma.  Flavor is a fairly typical red with a nice roast in the finish.  Solid brew for easy drinking.

Pours a slightly cloudy golden copper/dark ruby red color with dark golden orange hues when held to a light source and a one finger off white head that quickly settles into a thin lasting ring.

Slightly toasty malt aroma with hints of caramel, nut and toffee along with a prominent earthy, piny hop presence. Theres also some slight biscuit and citrus fruit character.

Very hop forward for the style and on the lighter end of medium body. Lots of dry earthy bitterness with some dry sticky pine along with some sweet citrus notes. There is a nice slightly toasty caramel malt backbone that provides some balance with hints of toffee, nut and biscuit. Although there is some decent balance this beer is very, very dry and is dominated by the bitter piny hops. Not much like an Irish Ale at all really but is still pretty tasty. Long dry bitter hoppy finish.

Boulevard Brewing Company--Irish Ale--Spring Seasonal--Bottle Conditioned--2010 12 oz. Bottle.  5.80% ABV--28 IBUs.  (3.8 / 5.0)  Irish Red Ale.  No sediment.  Rich lacy off white head.  Clear bright dark amber red color.  Malty mild hop toasted front.  Cloying sweet toasted caramel dry apple cherry doughy malty body.  Finishes clean with mild hop spice edge on lingering malt.  Malt focus,mild fruit.  Rich Irish Red.  Sampled 2/27/2010.  6-Pack $7.99.

Sweet nose with strong baked apple notes.  Beautiful hazed amber body with moderate carbonation.  Surface level toasted malt character that I can see going stale quickly but stays on the right side of fresh from this bottle.  Some graham cracker sweetness and a strong cereal malt note.  Barley  presence in a grape-nuts soaked in skim milk essence. pear and light citrus round out the drink. lingering on the slight tart finish.  A little sticky and sweeter than I like in this style but overall a nice offering.

Bottle from Frugal MacDoogal. Pours a very nice deep copper red with light grayish head, webby lacing. Aroma of ale esters, fruity, and cookie dough. Nice caramelly and nutty malt backbone countered by a non assertive herbal bitterness that carries through to the finish. Somewhat yeasty and dusty on the tail end. Moderately sweet.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2015 Poured from bottle. Brilliant red brown with a nice head, though it dissipated quickly. Aroma of dark malt, a touch of fruit and spice. Taste is nicely balanced, with rich caramel malts bouncing off of pronounced hops. With beers like this, who needs Smithwicks?
Bottle. Pours copper with a small beige head. Roasted malt aroma. Medium body with frothy carbonation. Flavor is slightly harsh roast malt with some fresh citric hop. Heads towards toffee. Tasty.

12oz bottle via trade thanks to stephens101 on BA.  Excellent appearance, deep red with a larger off-white head.  Great retention and lacing.  Aroma is bready and earthy, with mild roasted notes.  Pleasant flavor dominated by malts - bread and caramel.  Also lots of dirty earth, which is not a bad thing.  I mean, if you dont like earth, buddy, then get off it and go live on f-ing Uranus or something.  I hear its nice this time of year.  Bitter hop finish.  Medium-bodied, fairly dry with just a hint of sweetness in the middle.  Overall this is a pretty good example of a style that isnt one of my favorites.

Bottle.  Pours reddish copper with a medium off-white head.  Aroma is of bready malt, some citrusy hops, and a bit of metal.  Flavor is more of the same:  medium malt, medium hops.  This is a very smooth, clean, tasty beer.  Nothing funny, nothing fancy -- just really tasty.
Dark copper with a thick off white head that lingers around for a while.  Malty bread aroma and taste that is balanced out with a nice amount of hops.  Nice level of carbonation with a clean finish.

pours a cloudy copper with a large tan head, and some lacing.

smell is of sour malt, earth, some caramel, and a touch of cedar.

taste is tart, sour malt, caramel, spice, dirt, a hint salmon berry, and grain, ends a little dry, tart, and bitter.

(Draught at Libertine for St. Pattys Day) This beer pours a very dark red color with little to no head, and minimal lacing that doesnt coat the glass except on sides where I havent drank from. Smell is light roastiness, typical red ale with no skunkiness, sweet malts are present as well. Taste is very sweet without the roasty/toasty flavors associated with most red beers. A little bit undercarbonated which goes along well with this style, but I would have preferred more anyway. Its also a little bit thin. Could drink this one all night!

Reviewed from notes. Sampled last March. Poured a copper/red color. There wasnt much of a smell, but what smell there was came across as malty. The taste was malty with only a slight amount of hops. I havent had a ton of Irish Red Ales, but this one tasted good to me. I would definitely try it again.

-Date Tasted : 1-13-10
-Rating : 3.4

-Mode : 12oz. bottle

-Appearance : Great white color and light head with pretty standard lace, beer is amber and red in color like an Irish beer should be, I slight haziness apparent.
