-Flavor : Nice smooth at first presentation to the palate. Good balanced malt follows with the underlying hops, the malts stick with you long after a sip and so does a metallic aftertaste
-Overall : Impressed by this beer, I was not expecting this tasty of a beer. Great spring seasonal coming from Boulevard Brewing Co. my only complaint is the metallic finish. Drink up this seasonal.
Ruby tinted amber, toffee kissed white head, sticky lacing.  Little toast, concord grape? aroma.  Light bodied, dry leafy core, subdued hop finish.  Got a bit soapy toward the bottom of the glass.

12oz twist off bottle from 99 Bottles.  Pours a clear rich copper amber with a perfect 2 finger dirty white head.  Lightly to moderately sweet honey, toffee and brown sugar with some biscuity malt.  Also a bit of dust and wet soil.  Flavor is pretty much what the nose leads me to think I am getting into.  Light body, maybe a bit thin, with moderately sharp carbonation.  Straight forward sweet, slightly fruity, light malt and some hints of metallic.  No glaring faults, just nothing I would feel like I need to revisit.
Pours amber/red with a creamy white head.  Malt and hop aromas.  Caramel, malt, and hop flavors.  Nice balance.
Bottle.  Buttery caramel malt and grassy hops aroma.  Copper color with small head.   Milk caramel malt and moderate grassy hops flavor.  Medium body.  A nice beer - hoppy for an Irish ale.
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 BOTTLE: clear amber pour, offwhite head. Nose is yeast and dough, taste is caramel, hops, with a semi-dry finish. Decent brew.

Picked up a 12-oz bottle from Cellars Wine & Spirits in St Paul, MN. Pours a clear reddish amber brew with a fast dissolving beige head that dissipates to a thin off-white ring. Aroma of multi-grain cereal malt, some flowery hops, a touch of yeast and herbal spice. Taste is medium bodied, some carbonation with flavors of biscuit bread dough, flowery hops, some sweet citrus. Finish is slightly metallic and light with a citrus aftertaste the quickly disappears. A solid Irish ale at best.

Bottle. Pours a clear amber with a small frothy off white head that lasts awhile leaving good sticky lacing along the glass. The aroma is a sweet fruit malt with dough and smoke. Medium mouthfeel with a light toasty malt with caramel and a nice bitter finish. A very good Irish ale from Boulevard.

Barely hazy reddish-copper hue with a medium soapy off-white head.  Aroma is quite strong on the biscuit dough and sweet malt with a bit of flowery Kent hops aroma.  The flavor plays along, with a nice complex malt base with a light roast, a spicy sweet middle, and a nice dry bitter finish.

This may not set your hair on fire, but its a very nice Irish and perfect in either spring or fall (except that whole freshness thing!)

A very fine Irish ale. Brownish red pour with a medium sized white head. Flavor of malts and very hoppy. Goes down nice and smooth with the hops the prominate taste on the back of the tongue. Very good!"

Bottle.  Pours a clear, amber body with a large, tan, foamy head.  Aroma of sweet malt, toast, and a bit of biscuit.  Thick, sticky malt flavor with more toast, some herbal hops and mild raisin.  Medium body with light carbonation and a mild, bitter, clean finish.  Some lingering toast.  Enjoyable Irish ale.

Bottle.  Nice copper pour with a large sudsy head.  Sweet maltiness (Munich?)  combines with noble hops (probably dry-hopped).  Dry hoppy taste, sticky malt with light roast/toast and nuttiness.  Very faint chocolate and spicy toffee.  Hop smack toward the end, a touch of alcohol showing, very well balanced and delicious.  Very nice, reminds of where Upland was headed with their Irish before the alcohol started to amp up.
Had this on tap at an Old Chicago during the season and in order to help complete a world beer tour...
Pours amber with a white head.  Smells of sweet malt, rosey, fruity.  Tastes of caramel, some fruity hints.  Earthy finish.
Amber colored pour...frothy white head. Malty flavor is apparent. Little bit of fruit.possibly apple. Nice crisp finish on the palate.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2009 Pours amber colour with medium tan head.
Aroma is biscuity and caramel maltiness.
Light fruity hop.
Flavour is toasty caramel, some buttery tones and finishes with a light bitterness.

Amber pour into tan foamy head that quickly dissipates into a ring of lacing as a small amount of carbonated bubbles rise from the bottom of the glass. Aroma of toasted caramel malt and flowery hops. Initial flavor of toasted malt with a slighly hoppy finish that quickly fades into malty yet buttery sweetness.
(bottle). Pours a cloudy amber color. Medium tan head. Malty aroma.  Malt flavor with light roasted character. Avg duration. Spare lacing. Thin texture. Moderate carbonation.

Pours a deep redish,  brown with a small white head that doesnt last long. Aroma is a lot of earthy cereal and toasted biscuit malt with almost no hops at all. Flavor is a mad mix of malt, very delicious. Almost like a scotch ale, but a little lighter, and with an Irish whiskey kick and a nice earthyness. Hops are present on the finish, however, being Golding, they do balance a little, but remain mostly hidden in the backdrop. A nice mouthfeel with light carbonation and rich malt. 
Not a lot of hops present in both flavor and aroma, but the style IS more malt-based. Overall a little sweeter than I prefer, but a great all around Irish Ale. Would prefer over other IAs Ive had.

My favorite Irish ale.. And I love this brewery. NIce amber in Color with some fizzy white head... Smells of malt and lucky charms... Really nice and ample carbonation that helps with the beers slightly bitter finish. Lots of sweet malt on the flavor but also has a distinctive hop backbone.... Very balanced and I wish it was made year round
Amber brown with a small head. Aroma is sweet with some hops. Some earthy malts balance it out. Drinkable and a very nice red.

Picked up a case from my local store as it was on sale for $3.99/6pk.  Lets see how it rates... Cloudy orange brown in appearance, toasty malt aroma and a roasted malt flavor & sweet aftertaste.  Overall, a nice solid effort from Boulevard (which is becoming a favorite brewer of mine).

bottle thanks to boomer0813.  poured a hazy amber with a beige head.  aroma of caramel, hops, citrus, and orange peel.  flavor was caramel, citrus, with some good bitterness.  body was light with high carbonation.

Bottle.  Poured a murky reddish brown with a persistant off white head.  Aroma of toasted and sweet malt, caramel and fruit.  A pretty easy beer to drink, although their is some harshness in the palate.  Alot of caramel and nutty notes.  Some sweetness.  After taste wasnt great.  An ok beer.

Pours a nice reddish brown with good head retention, however small the head may be (sort of espresso like)
 The aroma is fruity with apples and some cherry and a good grainy maltiness. The flavor is malty with good cherry and nutty notes. There is a solid caramel character here as well and an ever-present hop flavor that does not seem to overpower a damn thing.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs: Only picked up a 12oz bottle of this since Im not an Irish style ale lover but it was worth a drink because it was from Boulevard Brewing. Created a thick fizzy of pillow foaming and color was an auburn orange. Sweet and malty is me easily describing the aroma in a quick nutshell. The flavor is extremely similar to a sun tea with no sweetener or lemon added and in my opinion tasted to bland and boring but it did surprise me with the tea and malt based flavor it had.
Pours red. Very smooth and very drinkable. I would not complain if they made this a year round.
Crushed with Jakebra at Mountain Sun.  Malty and incredibly smooth to drink.  It just doesnt have much else going for it.  Very drinkable but not very exciting.
Sample at March 27, 2009 beer club meeting. Has an amber-red color with a toasty aroma.  Flavor is a little hoppy.  Light mouthfeel.  Huh, almost tastes like black tea...
Bottled. Pours light brown with a medium tan head. Aromas of hops and caramel. Tastes of burnt chocolate and citrus--an interesting combination that different than most. Finishes watered down.

A crisp clean texture and mouth feel. Very enjoyable.  Medium amber color with quickly diminishing white head.  Caramel and toffee in the initial flavor.  Has a little dryness that equals out the sweetness.  Very well balanced.  I would definitely drink this one again.
Pours deep red with thin white foam.  Toffee, caramel, citrus, and a very slight hop nose.  Flavor is very sweet, with toasty and roasted flavors, caramel, and a nice earthyness.

Bottle.  Poured a deep crimson color with a 1/2 inch off-white head that faded to a layer.  Aroma of brown sugar, soft caramel, a light fruitiness (faint orange and a bit of berry), and some soft floral hops.  Smooth, moderately sweet entry with some light toasted malt and some light caramel that leads into a moderately bitter, earthy hop hit with some fruity undertones (apple oddly enough) paired with a bit of soft caramel on the finish.  Moderate carbonation and average mouthfeel.  Solid Irish which utilized its ingredients well.  While it isnt complex, it is an easy drinker.

Sampled at Flying Saucer in Little Rock. Pours a nice copper with very little head. Aroma is extremely hoppy for an irish red ale with a minute amount of caramel in the background. Taste is very hoppy, smooth, and good. However, I am really unsure that they poured me the right beer?

Pours a dark maple red .. damn impressive foam on the pour..what about Emilia?? dont worry about her... light ruby syrup and light red fruits in the nose... big amount of bitters for an irish ... good lacing .. nothing much in way of mouth or complexity, just run of the mill but no offensive details in this one.. very drinkable, id have one on st pattys but thats it... i like how its more bitter than sweet, bcuz most american versions are too cloying... a well made beer that i gave extra points to for its structure rather than my real enjoyment +2 points...

this was a fun beer and a nice break from the all ipa and stout diet i have been on recently.   lots of nice maltiness to chew through, i may as well call it toasty as in the commercial description, but i did not detect the toasted hops that bluemooner describes below.
Bottle from World Market.  Aroma was less then impressive, pured dark amber/brownish, flaver was pretty balanced, good hop spices, left a lingering after-taste on the palate.

Pours a dark amber with average size, creamy off-white head.  Aroma of toasted malt, slight caramel, toffee and smoke flavors.  Slightly earthy, yeasty.  Bottle conditioned.  Lacing mostly diminishes.  Taste is lightly sweet with a slight bitter finish.  Medium bodied with soft carbonation and light alcohol presence.  Pretty good for its class.
Pours a dark amber brown color with a medium tan head. Nice flavors of malts, nuts, caramel, toffe, and toasty hops. Decent beer and a very good Irish ale.

I was pretty excited to see this one at Steves. Im also happy overall to find Boulevard beers in my neck of the woods. Poured a breautiful, translucent amber colour with a very fine white head. Plenty of carbonation, just not much in the froth. Aroma is pleasent, a little hint of caramel and smoke possibly hidden, very subtley. Flavours of something sweet, like maybe a little maple syrup or something- otherwise finishes slightly bitter. I guess i may be comparing this too much to the Great Lakes Irish because its probably one of my favorites and most recent. Anyway, ill be trying this agian for sure.
Clear red, tall head. Light cherry aroma, otherwise weak. Weak taste, not very pleasant finish. The taste dies off quickly. Reminds me of cough syrup.

Good deep cloudy amber with a nice tan head. Aroma of British hops and a balanced malt blend. Taste is balanced and mild but full and mostly malt with a caramel nut finish. Good for the style, albeit a little bitter.

Pours dark brownish amber with a 2 finger slimy looking beige head. Aroma is grass, grainy malt, biscuit, fruity notes, and some planty hops. Flavor is raw grain, toast, wood notes, grass, light fruit, raw nuts, citrus and some caramel. Finish is slightly bitter and planty. Palate is thin, slightly sweet and has a slightly drying finish, very clean and crisp. A very good beer, available at a great price in my area.

12oz bottle from BevMo! Mission Valley.  Pours a nice blood orange amber with a big n thick beige head, nice lacing left on the glass.  Nice roasty aroma with some hazel nut and toffee hints.  A very crisp and clean finish.
Bottle. Poured amber with a creamy off-white head. Aroma of toasted malts and spices. The flavor is slightly fruity with a light hop background. Medium body, dry, balanced but plain.

Usually I really like the Boulevard products.  Somehow, for me, this one missed the mark.  It is not much more than an average Irish Ale in my book.  Looks like by the total average rating I am outnumbered...oh well, personal preference.
Pours a medium brown with little to no head.  aroma of malt and brown sugar.  Initial taste of Molasses and malt.  very smooth finish.

From a bottle provided by dm9831 - It poured a clear reddish amber body with a substantial ecru head but little lace.  The aroma is sweet and malty with a touch of butterscotch and some herbal/floral hoppiness.  The flavor is smooth and malty, has some toast and a hint of orchard fruit, all balanced out by a moderate bitterness.  Dry finish.  Nice sessionable ale.

IFrom a bottle poured a dark slightly hazy amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet with quite a lot of fruit and hops combined with light notes of caramel. The flavor ihas a very dry bitter end.

Think of it as a bitter Killians. Its not terrible, but I can think of any number of ales Id rather have. Its got a bitter aftertaste and has virtually no complexity of flavor. Again, its really not horrible, but I probably wont be getting this one again.
I was pretty surprised that I hadnt rated this one.  Amber in color with a small thin, off-white head.  Nice, spicy flavor.  This was better than I expected.
Pours orange to amber, thin brown head, cinnamon malt aroma, dry hops are balanced with sweet tones, leaves a roasted dry aftertaste, very balanced.
Bottle from BevMo. Deep maroonish in color. Dried bready aroma with a bit of earthiness. Dry and malty flavors up front. Good malt character. Some English hoppiness. Very bitter finish.

Pours from the bottle red in color with a light tan head which lasts a long time.  The head has a rich, creamy appearance. Aroma of caramel and light toast with some earthy notes. The caramel notes in the flavor blend nicely with the bitterness of the hops.  The flavor starts sweet, and has a lenghty, earthy finish.  The mouthfeel i a little creamy, but finishes dry.

Draft pint at Barleys. Darkish red-brown with a small, creamy disc of bubbles. Faint toasted nut and dry yeast aromas. Tastes of toasted nut, lightly sour caramel apple, dried wood and a hint of cocoa. Almost-medium body is watery, kinda smooth and roasty-dryish.

Draught at Barleys in Knoxville. Pours reddish mahogany with thin, sticky beige head. The aroma is buttered toast, some biscuit, and a roasty note. The flavor is light caramel, cola, graininess, and a little bit of leather. Clean finish. Decent, but textbook enough to be kind of boring.
Bottle. Pours an amber color with a one finger head. Decent hops. Aroma is hops and malts. Dry finish, Decent
UPDATED: MAR 5, 2009 A great seasonal beer from Boulevard.  Sweet toasted malt beer, kinda dry.  Im not a fan of really heavy beers, but this one really isnt too bad.
Aroma of fruit and hops....some hints of citrus and berry. Sweet, creamy flavor with notes of caramel, toffee and citrus. Dry finish.

clear dark amber color, thin, quickly disappearing tan head, no lacing.    nose is sweet malt with fruity notes.  falvor is much like nose, sweet malt, dry fruit, caramel.  medium body, very dry lightly bitter finish.  well balanced, and the hint of alcohol (and its only 5.3% abv) is quite welcome.  6 pack purchased at convenience store down the street from my st. louis hotel.

Poured from 12oz bottle into pint glass.
Appearance - Brownish red with off-white 2 finger head. Good lacing.
Aroma & Flavor - Carmel malt with some faint notes of fruit. Light on the hops.
Palate - Medium mouthfeel. Proper amount of carbonation for the style
Overall - This is one of my favorite styles for session drinking. A good example of an Irish ale. I could drink a few of these!

12 oz bottle purchased at Woodys in Nashville.  Poured a clear amber color with a one finger off white head.  The aroma had notes of smoke, peated malt and even a hint of citrus.  The flavor was rather bland and malty, with biscuit and toasted bread dominating.  The palate was average with good carbonation, a medium body and a chewy mouthfeel.  This was a decent, drinkable beer.  Not my favorite though.

Bottle split with Barrios at woodys.  Hazy orange brown pour with a ring of tan head.  Nose of malt, smoke, peat, and some alcohol despite being low alc.  Flavor is toasty, biscuit, and acidic.  Average blah.
Nice red-orange with a red tinted tan head.  Toasty aroma, slightly metallic, berry or apple fruitiness and caramel.  Taste is nicely toasted malt sweetness, bready with a lasting bitter finish.

12oz bottle with Butters.  Pours a light tan head with an amber body.  Smells of caramel and light toast.  Tastes of caramel and toast.  Reminds me a little of caramel corn.  Very slight bitterness on the finish.
Bottle, extra in a trade.  Pours a mahogany body with a one finger tan head.  Sweet caramel malt, nice floral earthy hop character.  Light toasty malt body with a nutty feel as well.

Not fantastic or anything overly special. Overall a nice drinkable beer that I will keep around as a session beer. Malty, with nice medium hop aroma and very slight grapefruity hop finish on the backend. Pours beautifully, but the head disspiates very fast. To me it is a "Nut Cracker" (BLVDs winter warmer) Light.
Reddish copper, thin beige head. Bready, toasty aroma. Flavor is also bready and toast, with hints of cola and maybe a woodsy note, as well. Fairly simple, but tasty.

On tap in KC. Pours a pretty clear amber brown body with a thin beige head that dissipates quickly and remains slightly lacy and swirly on the surface. Aroma is sweet caramel malts, some citrus fruitiness, and slightly roasted. Flavor is initially sweet and citrusy, but finishes with a mild to light bitterness and some roasted malt. Smooth caramel and a bit of earthy character to it. Palate is medium bodied, creamy, and slightly dry in the finish. Overall, another nice sipper from Boulevard. Im normally not an irish ale fan, but this one has a nice amount of flavor throughout and a pretty nice finishing bitterness. Very pleasant balance. Good seasonal offering.
Deep copper color with an average head.  Aroma is hoppy with a slight malt aroma.  Dry on the palate.  Very hoppy for the style with a slight malt finish.

A nice looking caramel color beer with a nice tan head and good visible carbonation. Aroma is caramel malt, earth, and some hop tanginess. Flavor is barley, malt, and some grapefruit notes. As it warmed the tartness faded a bit and the malt moved to the front along with some spice. Interesting Irish with the hop profile.
Golden red, toasty aroma but balanced with notes of something sweet...can’t put my finger on it.  Flavor of malts, nuts, toast.  Thin but smooth and dry finished, well balanced.

Hazy red-brown with slowly dissipating thin off-white head.  Aroma of toasted malts, nuts, sweet malts, caramel, brown sugar and mild citrus.  Taste of caramel, nuts, sweet malt and mild citrus.  A little thin on the body with a dry finish.

Poured from the bottle dark red-brown in color with a small head that diminished after a minute or so.  Aroma is sweet caramel with a good ester nose. Flavor is malty sweet, dry at the start and a great light creaminess throughout the drink.  As it warms, the aroma notes really permeate the nose and enhances the flavor quite well.   Pretty good Irish ale.

Caramel. Caramel. Love this brew though the caramel is somewhat overbearing. Smooth though. I have never had any complaints with boulevard brewing company. they put out fine products and this coming from an irishman, is one of their best. to note the nose gets better as you go.

Bottle Lightly hazed mahogany ale with a small, frothy, off-white head. Decent retention. Earthy, vinous aroma. Malty with lots of minerals and port esters. Medium-bodied and ultra-creamy with ticklish carbonation. Medium metallic bitterness surrounds a sturdy malt framework. Lengthy finish that is caramel-sweet up front, yet moderately bitter on the back of the tongue. A big THANKS goes out to headbanger for shipping this bottle to me!

12 oz. bottle. Pours a deep amber with a nice tan head that sticks around. Aromas dominated by a caramel malt and light hoppiness follows suit. Initial taste is lighter than expected, Lighter caramel malt, a nice little citrusy hop bite that turns smooth and then gives way to a little bitter finish that leaves a pleasant caramel malt aftertaste and a faint spiciness. A beautiful medium bodied brew that smells wonderful and tastes pretty good too, albeit a little less than anticipated. Overall, very pleased with a beer I would have never picked up otherwise.
bottle, medium head that quickly fades, red amber color with fruity malt nose, good hoppy malt flavor with hints of caramel and grapefruit, smooth finish

Bottle. Tawny brown body with a thick foamy beige head. Nose-big nose, sweet dust, stale hops, seltzer water, unsweet cola, crystal malts. Taste-good unsweet crystal malt, nice well rounded stale hops, great mouthfeel, perfect sweetens, great lactic, creamy, good brown ale notes, semi-dry, just a perfect mix of brown ale and creaminess, hops and malt are well done 9which, as an aside, is probably a good thing for a beer). An excellent rendition of a boring style. A perfect session beer.

A nice looking caramel color beer with a nice tan head and good visible carbonation.  Aroma is caramel malt, earth, and some hop tanginess.  Flavor is barley, malt, and some grapefruit notes.  As it warmed the tartness faded a bit and the malt moved to the front along with some spice.  Interesting Irish with the hop profile.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy red amber color with a nice frothy tan head.  Taste and Aroma are of smoke, roasted malts and caramel.  Has a smoke aftertaste.  Is a little watery.  A pretty good beer overall, as is very easy to drink and tastes pretty good.
Bottle (Thanks Al).  A nice light red color with creamy white head.  Malty aroma and smooth malty flavor.
deep amber pour with a thin cream head.  spicy malt scent.  ok on the palate with a sweet bitter taste.

HogTownHarrys bottle, shared with me :-) An odd take (to me) on an Irish Ale: Amber brown colour, small grey head which was easily enlarged by swirling. Slight malt aroma with some beer-earth there too, some sweetness. Flavour: Sweet nut like flavour with some spice too, quite nice actually, but to me, not an Irish Ale

Bottle (12oz).  Shared with garthicus, my bottle via trade with mreusch.  Shared with someone who should know "Irish" when he tastes it ... he liked it, but cant recall ever smelling or tasting anything like this back home ...  Poured slightly hazy copper with a small wispy drool of off-white head.  Odd perfume/floral aroma, reminded me of fruit-flavoured Pez, with sweet caramel malt underlying it.  The taste had plenty of floral sweetness, but it had a welcome pungency that seemed to pass for bitterness - regardless, it seemed a little more balanced than I was expecting.  A thick, syrupy body to this, with mild carbonation, not much alcohol character, and a long pungent floral/raw spice linger.  The aroma seemed a little sweet, but I found I really enjoyed that flavour.
Thanks bort11 for your generousity.  Pours a tan yellow with a foaming white head.  Beery cheese aroma.  Aggressive carbonation,not bad but oh so dry Irish.

12oz bottle-A medium amber body with a decent tan head that dissipates into a small ring. Aroma of malt and thats about it. Taste begins with this malt and it continues throughout along with some caramel and has a bit more sweetness and dryness as well. Not a bad beer.

All my brews tonight courtesy of Soonah. Thanks! Bottle, Pours a slightly hazy brownish-red. Very faint aroma, an earthy maltiness. Thin head,. Tastes vegetal to me. Kind of like broccoli. Definitely not a fan of this one.

Pours a nice deep copper color with a full off-white head.  There is a nice, complex roasted malt flavor that adds a wonderful smoky touch, but is kept in check by a fair amount of hops.  I like scotch, and my favorite is single malt Islay, which has a deep smoky peat flavor, so that probably explains why I like this brew so much.  I would like to pair this brew with a Welsh rabbit dish that uses a good sharp cheddar cheese and crusty bread.  Stilton cheese would also go nicely with this brew.

(12oz bottle, thanks kmweaver) Clear copper body with small beige head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, some berry, faint peat.  Taste is medium sweet, caramel, light earthy, roast.  Light-medium body.

Courtesy of kmweaver. Hazy amber body with a medium-sized beige head. Bready, cracker nose with light caramel and herbal hops. Lightly sweet, lightly bitter taste with cracker, vienna malts, cookie dough and herbs. Medium/light body is round with moderate carbonation.

12oz bottle, courtesy of pepsican.  Thanks, Andy!  Pours a hazy, reddish tea-like color; light tan head with fine-bubbled lacing.  Solid amounts of tea, earthiness, and mineral hop bitterness in the aroma.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: crisp carbonation; lively citrus and earthy bitterness, candy sugar; biscuity malts; the English bitterness is soft, slightly chewy; very nice, drinkable beer.  Medium finish: breadiness, earthy malts, and some lingering bitterness.

Bottle.  Pour is a lovely copper/amber color with a two-finger tan head.  Aromas are of bread dough maltiness with a bit of a piney character to the hops which makes it smell fresh and crisp.  The resin-like hops doesnt come through much in the flavor, and taste is dominated by malty bread and caramel.  Still, its pretty decent.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: St. Pattys day. Aroma is caramel malt, grainy, a bit herbal as well. Lightly toasted grains, some smoke, and barley flavors. Finishes grassy and slighty bitter. An American take on an Irish red.

Oh, just to be predictable, a few irish style beers for st patricks.  This is not a bad start.  Pours a nice dark copper, an orangish head the fades pretty fast.  The smell is sweet with a hint of grassiness.  A nice malty flavor to it, but the body is a bit overly carbonated and bright to my tastes.  Its a solid effort.
Good Irish ale. has a pungent hit but it is good. love it . not as sweet as killigans

12 oz. bottle served in a shaker pint.
Pours a pretty reddish gold with a thick head. Crisp hop aroma with caramel malt.
Sweet maltiness up front, caramel. Medium bodied. Creamy mouthfeel. Fresh hop flavor. Very easy drinking. This beer is a great example of the beauty of fresh, local beer.
Nothing spectacular, but when you get it in season, it really shines.
On tap.  Has a nice brown color with white head.  Smells of hops and caramel.  Tastes great.  Nice balance...love the hops in this one!  Medium body with a slightly bitter aftertaste.

Deep clear- amber in color, has a nice white head that doesnt last very long, light malty bready aroma. Sweet caremel malty flavor, mild hop profile it does have a nice clean dry finish, medium body, seems kind of bland, overall not all that bad but average.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2010 Nice brew, but wouldnt be something wed rush out to buy more of . . .  Poured from the bottle an almost clear, darkish copper color with a thin, short-lived, light-tan head.  Hops and yeast dominate the aroma.  Nicely hopped and carbonated.  Would agree with an earlier rater that mentioned the similarities to Fat Tire -- except this is a bit stronger, with a bit more bitterness and overall flavor.
Hoppy, yeasty aroma with a thin head.  Nice lacing and carbonation.  Warm, rich amber/light brown in color.  Bitter and hoppy from start to finish, sharp and crisp.  Sure beats Killians.
full disclosure: I dont love irish ales. This one was okay but not fantastic. had on draft at Dressels in St. Louis, good looking beer but a bit sour.
Pours copper with a descent head. Flavor is a good balance between the hops and malt. Reminiscent of an APA.
12 oz bottle pours a copper color with a half inch beige head.  Aroma is of light hops and grain.  Flavor is slightly bitter with a nice malty balance.

Thank you ilovedarkbeer for this. Aroma is moderate English style hops with some toasted malts. Creamy off-white head. A medium honey brown color. Taste is very malty and quite watery, but still nice. Nothing to special. Watery mouthfeel with pleasent carbonation.

This one  left me less than impressed. I was quite excited for what was supposed to be one of the top irish ales. Pours a pure amber color with a tope colored head. The medium to small sized head stuck around for a small period of time. Nose is of toasted malt, burt caramel, some wheat, and english style hops. Taste is watery and very typical of the rest of boulevards brews. There are many things about this beer that remind me of NBs fat tire but I would also say it is not as good or balanced. Just so-so

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2008 Deep amber body with an off-white head. The head dissipated quickly, though, and there wasnt a lace to speak of. Fruity and somewhat acidic aroma at first, and then just plain dried fruit after the head diminished. Malty and subdued dried fruit flavors initially, and then the hops appeared in the finish. The aftertaste seems to be dominated by the malts, but I guess thats to be expected with this style. The flavor is best experienced as the beer warms up a bit, so Id recommend that you dont serve it too cold. Good carbonation, yet I think it might be a little on the fizzy side. Overall, this is a respectable beer, but one six-pack will probably be enough for the season.

(Bottle) Pours a dark brown color with good lacing. Dry, dusty aroma includes light hops and an earthy undertone. Taste includes some moderate hoppy notes, roasted grain, and sweet caramel. Rather thick mouthfeel is slightly sticky, but by no means cloying. Light carbonation. A better than expected offering from Boulevard.
Deep copper color with an average head.  Some hops and malts in the aroma.  Somewhat hoppy with a light malt finish.  Small wheat barely changes the flavor.

12oz Stubby

Best by 5/1/08

I got this bottle as an extra in a recent trade with Vancer, thanks again Vance! Boulevards Irish Ale pours a fairly clear amber but upon closer inspection theres some tiny floating sediment that takes away a bit of the clarity. A one finger white head appeared on the pour that fell to a thin cap and left spotty lacing on its way down.

A bit of caramel and toasty malts greet the nose upfront. Theres a noticeble earthy spiy hoppiness throught. Maybe my minds plying tricks on me but every now and then I pick up a whiff of pineapple.

While not an exciting ale this is a good one. Irish reds seem to be a tough style to really make stand out and Boulevards version is no different but it is enjoyable. A solid helping of caramel maltiness is accompanied by a touch of toasted graininess. The hopping creates a nice balance and rings in earthy and spicy just like the aroma suggested. Finishes with a touch of lingering bitterness.

This beer sports a medium body with a smooth velvetiness. The mouthfeel fits the style really well and keeps it an enjoyable drinker.

Drinkability is good. The balanced flavor, mouthfeel, and low abv all make for a truly quaffable Irish red.

A good example of hte style from Boulevard. Irish Reds are a style I cant really get to excited about but this would be a good beer to drink if you were sitting down for a game or in a more social situation where more than a few would be consumed in a night. Thanks Vance!

2/8/08

Good beer....Pored a deep reddish color with off white head, good retention and somewhat laced the glass. Aroma is floral and fruity. Has a nice malty taste with fruity and hoppy notes, slight bitter at the end. Mouth feel is very well balanced. Would drink again.

Draught:  This one pours a fairly clear, amber color.  there was a bit of a head on it, and it left some lacing down the glass.  The aroma was a bit light.  What was there was pleasant, with notes of roast and a bit of caramel.  It does taste pretty good.  Taste is slightly caramel malt sweet, with a hint of roastiness.  Hint of hops providing a nice balance.

Tasted 1/22/08.  12oz bottle.  Filtered with an amber brown hue.  Trace head.  Toasty rye bready aromas.  Touch mild hops in the nose.  Medium bodied and very well balanced.  Good malts with a touch of bitterness.  Mildly effervescent.  Nice dry hop finish.  Short lived lingering grassy stickiness.  Touch burnt, but it accentuates the blaance, if not the relative balance.  Nice and dry throughout.  Tasty brew!
ON TAP: nice copper amber color.  Caramel hints, slightly dry with a malty, refreshing mouth feel and a crisp finish.  Enjoyed it.

Blvd Brewing creates a very good spring ale with a nose of Saaz hops and Pale Malt.  The head is not lasting, but in the bottle a quick flick of the wrist produces a solid 1+ inch head.  The color is right for the style and it is medium to light bodied beer.
Bottle.  Hazy amber brown brew with a tiny head.  Aroma is sweet and fruity with a noticeable hop and caramel.  Flavor is sweet with a nice hop.  Dry fruit undertones.

Not really sure why I havent rated this, I have certainly drank a lot over the years. 12oz bottle from this years release which has been on the shelves less than a week. Served in a pint glass. This is my third Blvd Irish Ale tonight. Aroma is caramel, toffee, and toasty with some floral, light fruits and earthy hops. Copper colored with an off-white head. The taste is all about the malt and is toasty, melanoidin rich, caramel and toffee with some nice floral and lightly earthy hops to balance it out. Very drinkable. Always a treat this time of year.

Bottle courtesy of dadplus2. Pours a lightly hazy reddish brown with a small, creamy, beige head. The nose is lightly toasty malt, caramel and faint floral and earthy hops; clean but fairly muted. Fairly light-bodied with soft carbonation and a crisp, clean, lightly hoppy finish. The flavor is of toasted and slightly astringent caramel malt with a tight, lightly bitter finish featuring solid notes of floral and mildly earthy hops. This is the last of Boulevards four seasonal beers that Ive sampled. Like its three predecessors, this is a well-made and tasty brew. Aside from the Smokestack series, I find their seasonals to be their best beers. Thanks again for this bottle, Mark!
Nice Ale!   Red and hearty and good for most everything that ails you.   A good take on a traditional Irish Red.   This Red tops Leinies and Killigans...   by a long shot.

This beer comes a little late for St. Pattys day.  Im not sure I can tell the difference between this and an amber.  This beer isnt anything special, though I am not a fan of the style that much either.
Excited to see it come around each year. Starts as if it were a stout lightened up a bit. Nice amber color, semi-strong, ale.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2010 Toasted malt, earthy aroma.  Prominent roasted malt with spice, fruit, and caramel notes. Moderate hop presence.
Dry crisp finish. Excellent Irish Ale.

Mahogany pour with fluffy tan head.  Strong, pleasant aroma is sweet and malty with hints of citrus...just delicious!  Flavor is dominated by malt flavors up front, but theres some reminders of hops near the end.  Slightly thin on the palate, but nothing too off for an Irish Ale.  Dry finish leaves you clamoring for more...a great example of the style by Boulevard!
Bottle, pours a dark red brown with a thin head. Light roast notes, very little hops finishes dry. But fairly watery.
Nice Dark orange color, decent fluffy head, a malty brew, but not overly sweet, some fruit, Bread. very easy drinking. Thanks to Duane for the brew!

A deep mahogany color with a thin white head. The aromas given off are malt, yeast, seem like a little caramel and hints of citrus. The taste is toasted malt hints of molasses, and a hint of citrus. There is a slight bitterness with a clean crisp finish. The body is medium to light. A good beer overall

Poured the color of murky iced tea with virtually no head. Mild roasted aroma, hops underlying. Flavor is the same but palate is a thin.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2007 Bottle.  Pours clear, light ruby with very small but constant bubbles.  Medium off-white head, mostly diminishing and little lacing.  Nose is cereal with toffee and some citrus hops.  Taste is cereal and bread.  Medium body with a thin but lively mouth-feel.  Finishes slightly bitter with some dryness... mild hops.  Theres nothing here that I dont like.

12-oz bottle received via trade with Duane.  Pours sparkling ruby with an average sized creamy off-white head, mostly lasting, good lacing.  Aroma is average malt (cereal, nutty), average hops (flowers, grass), average yeast (sweat) with notes of pear and paper.  Light bodied, thin texture, lively carbonation and an astringent finish.  Average duration, light sweetness, acidity and bitterness; foamy metal, raw hop and cereal malt flavor.

apparently little rock is code for boulevard country.  aroma of whiskey, carmel, orange, and english malts.  flavor is very malty with some whiskey, orange, lemon, carmel, and hints of chocoalte malt.  this was pretty frickking tasty IMO.
Pours dark amber, creamy white head. Malty with caramel, toffee, and toasty. Hops are slightly spicy and mild. I thought this was very good, balanced, and tasty.

Courtesy of Styles
Bottle:  The aroma is moderately fruity with grape and cherry with some raint roastiness and nuttiness.  It pours a bright transparent reddish-orange with a small off-white head that fades quickly.  The flavor starts with moderate fruit with lots of grape throughout.  The finish has some faint roastiness with minimal hops.  The mouthfeel is thin and watery with minimal carbonation.

bottle from soonah: pours a clear orange red colour with hardly any head. aroma is sweet caramel malt and slight citrus hop with some breadyness. flavour is tasty with a bread, malt, and a sutle hop bitterness to finish. the mouth feel is very full and thick. a real nice irish ale

Duane gave me a bottle of this.  Thanks Dad.  Had this one a while ago, forgot to rate it.  Going off of memory here...  Hazy orange/red color.  Malty, toffee like aroma.  Taste was very malty and dough like.  Not much going on  in the way of hops, but still a very smooth drinking, well balanced beer.
Poured a hazy amber with a small beige head.  Aged fruity malt aroma and flavor.  Some apple notes.  Light to medium body.

Bottle. Poured a reddish orange color with very little white head thinning out fast. Aroma is water and cleaning supplies. Taste at first is malty with a very very slight hint of hops at finish with malt.

Pours dark amber, creamy white head.
Malty with caramel, toffee, and toasty. Hops are slightly spicy and mild.  I thought this was very good, balanced, and tasty.
12 oz. bottle.  pours a deep, rich amber with a decent size off white head.  very malty aroma and flavor with an undertone of caramel and floral hops.

12oz bottle via trade with Duane! - Thanks! - Pours dark amber with a fair creamy offwhite head.  Aromas of caramel malts, toasted malts, a little toffee, some dough and nuts.  Flavor is quite malty with lots of caramel, toffee, nuts, some dough, and toasted malts.  Lots of earthiness as well.. Not many hops to be found.  Medium body with soft carbonation and a rich creamy mouthfeel.  Not bad at all..

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2007 Nothing really to point or note here other than it was darker than other irish ales Ive had.  The hops were more subtle than I would of liked.  A liltle bit oily. Overall the average medium character was OK, but it was pumped up by some locals, who said it was better than it was.

12 oz bottle from Soonah - thanks! Marked with a best by date of 05/01/07. Coppery brown with a tight beige head. Lightly toasty malt nose, some cookie and nuts. Nutty cookie flavors, a slight cinnamon note and mild earthiness. Decent brew.
UPDATED: JAN 24, 2010 Ever so slightly on the sweet sight.  Nicely balanced with ample carbonation for a nice bite.  I wish this was available all year.

Happy St. Patricks Day!  Poured a nice rich copper color upon which sat a nearly two-finger high off-white head.  The head was pillowy, borderline rocky and even offered up a bit of lacing.  The aroma was floral with some maltiness.  The flavor was a nice mix of sweet malt and subtle floral hops.  A bit of a twangy metallic aftertaste was disappointing.

aroma is caramel and toasted bread with some floral hop notes.   taste is caramel with some toffee and toast in there.  there maybe a tiny earthy hop tone.  the finish has slightly citrus and roast dryness to finish.  not to bad quite quaffable.

on tap at O Dowds Little Dublin, Kansas City MO.  brownish amber color, mostly clear, thin medium tan head.  aroma is caramel malt and stale roasted peanuts.  flavor is light roasted caramel malt, with papery/grassy dry hops.  finish is a little dry and bitter like a wheat beer.  unique for the style.

12 oz bottle from Royal in Kansas City, Missouri. Best by 04/12/10 stamped on the bottle. Pour is mostly clear copper amber with a thick full 2 inch light tan head. Aroma is mild biscuit caramel toasted malt along with a floral hoppiness. The two combine together for a sharpness, which makes it a bit abrasive. Taste is the sweetness of the nose, though now its equal parts caramel and fruit sweetness, followed by the floral hops and finishing with a nice mineral element.  The meld and balance between malt and hops works better in the taste versus the nose. Palate is thin to medium, crisp and dry on the finish - real easy to drink. Overall, clean and well made for the style; a style which has never really excited me. (5,4,7,3,13 - 3.2)
++++ Original Rating 5 March 2007 ++++
Bottle.  Pour is brown with just a touch of redness.  Smallish head that faded fast.  Aroma is real muted though I did get some hops and malt.  Taste is nice, solid malt accented with hops and bitterness building in the middle with a nice solid bitter finish.  Nice fullness to this as well. (5,4,7,4,13 - 3.3)

This used to be one of my favs!  It may have lost something over the years, but its still pretty good!  Poured medium/light brown with just a slight reddish hue.  Very small head which dissipated quickly.  Not much aroma to speak of.. Slightly bitter with a "bubbly" feel on the tongue.  Very drinkable!
Pours amber in color with a little head.  Little bit of a bitter taste and a good amount of carbonation
Bottle from Blue Max Liquors poured into English pint. Pours dark amber with very little head. Good lacing. Slight coffee aroma. Slightly bitter, very drinkable, overall a solid beer.

Bottle from Hy-Vee poured into english pint - Pours cranberry amber with a very small tan head; Sweet malts, some faint hops, vanilla and lots of strawberry to the nose; Reminded me of Big Red soda in a way; Good hops, malt and light roasty toasty notes on the initial taste; Much of the same minus the hops in the aftertaste; A more full medium body; Good carbonation; Way better than my first example of this style! The strawberry and vanilla were nice. Could easily drink this on a regular basis. Another great one by Boulevard.

Pours a four finger light tan head that fades slowly leaving some lace. Almost clear amber color. Light-medium carbonation and light-medium bodied. Slight malty nose. Starts almost sweet maybe caramel, clean finish. Hints of hops in aftertaste. Best by May 1, 2006. $1.49 for a 12oz bottle from Johns Grocery Iowa City, IA.
I have not met a Boulevard brew that I have not liked, maybe there are some I dont love but like, all. Irish Ale is no exception, this session ale pours red and has a very complex taste.

12 oz bottle via csbosox(thanks!). Best by 05/05...Pours a hazy dark brown with a large tan head. Nose is a bit fruity and a tad sour with notes of strawberries and vanilla. Taste is the same with some toasted malts and a little pepper and sourness in the finish. A Pretty good dark ale albeit not real fresh. Very drinkable though.

Draft. Amber tending toward red with haze.    Nice light  tan head that left good lacing.  nose is fruit, hops, and citurs. Kind of a roasted malt flavor with interesting hops to make a good taking brew.  Mouthfeel was above average.  A well crafted Irish Ale with good balance that is a pleasure to drink.
Pretty good, dinkable at the very least.  Has some sweet rich maltiness, full of caramel and some light fruit flavors as well.  Finishes slightly spicy, with some toasty burnt bread notes.

A dark slightly hazy amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is sweet with quite a lot of fruit and hops combined with light notes of caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of fruit, caramel, and light notes of alcohol, leading to a very dry bitter end.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Clear orangey brown with a small, beige coloured head. Aroma of caramel and roasted malt. Medium-bodied with sweetish, roasted malts and a discreet note of smoke. Sweetness and a dry hoppiness blends together perfectly to create a very harmonious brew. A lot closer to a Scottish Ale than to Kilkenny. Lovely. 250606

Bottle. Poured reddish brown with a huge frothy off-white head that lasted and produced good lacing. Moderate toasted sweet malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium sweet bitter flavor with a sweet finish of moderate duration. This beer would go well with spicy food or a cigar.

The 12 ounce bottle poured a slightly hazy reddish amber colored beverage with a medium sized cream colored fizzy head that lasted fairly well and left good lacing on the glass. The balance leaned slightly toward the hops side with a sweet floral hop aroma. Behind this the malt made itself known in the form of notes of roasted grains, hints of caramel and toast. The body was medium-full with lively carbonation and a sharp, dry texture. The flavor started off a bit sweet which quickly changed to a nicely balanced bitterness. This bitterness lasted throughout the medium-long finish and was accompanied by an alcohol warmth toward the end.
Poured red with good head and some lacing.  Not much in the way of aroma.  Taste was a weak irish red.

Deep Amber in color with a frothy creamy like head.  Caramel sweetness evident in the nose with slight fruitiness from esters.  Caramel sweetness is evedent in flavor with a lowbitterness to balance.  Toasted flavors come through in the back of the beer at the finish.  Light creaminess and maderate carbonation give this beer a very nice mouthfeel.  Over all a very drinkable beer.

Pours brown with a reddish hue.  Nice light tan head that goes away before too long.  Aroma has rich caramel malt that has a touch of dark fruit to it.  Rich caramel malt with with metallic aspects.  Finish is very astringent.  Not as good it has been in previous years, but not a bad beer.  Hopefully the astringency is taken out for next time.
Spicy and fruity, with a marked bitterness to it. Nothing too special, really. Wouldnt buy it again.

Bottle - courtesy of Mike at Bon Vivant. Copper body with a tall foamy tan head. Nose is fruity with caramel and spicy hops. Light flowery notes as well. Taste is hoppy and floral with light spice notes, dried fruits (apricot, orange) and almost a nutty trail mix type flavor. Body is slick and creamy with a moderate overall feel. Finishes with more of the same, pretty much - spicy hops, light floral notes, and dried fruits.
UPDATED: AUG 19, 2008 Fruity aroma smells like spring.  Flavor resembles the auroma;   Nice and springy.  Also discovered that if you drink enough of these, even the new season of Scrubs is funny.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2006 Courtesy of Mjames.

Very low key malt aroma with a smattering of hops, but it is very faint. Copper/amber color with a pinky thin amber head. Caramel malt in the fore..medium hop presence. very blah..not much going on.
Thanks to Degarth. Ruby red pour, white head. Grapefruit hops bigtime, grassy, malty, but nto much else going on, it was ok.

Thanks to my friends Tim & Naomi for this. 12 oz. Bottle. Pours clear amber/red with a good light tan head and creamy lacing.  Very appealing fruit and malt nose. Very smooth malt flavor with nice hop bitterness for a balance. Creamy texture. Overall a tasty beer.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2006 12 oz bottle. Pours a dark copper-amber with a small off-white head that fades rapidly and leaves little lacing.  Smells sweet, almost like vanilla.  The taste is sweet and bitter, the former being the latter.  Just barely a nutty taste throughout.  Complex to say the least.
Pours a nice amber color.  Not a lot of aroma, sweet malt with a hint of fruit/hops.  Flavor is malty, with a touch of bitterness.

Pours a dark amber with some darker reddish hues.  Not much in the head department.  Everthing about this beer points to sweetness.  Hops seem like they were forgetten.  Not real bitterness to speak of.  Dissapointing, because last year this was one of my favorites.  Thin, bubbley palate.  I hope the fix it for next year.
Pour is red with a small white head.  Aroma is malty but nothing really stands out.  Flavor is caramel and toffee with a touch of hops.  Overall nothing to overpower but its better than Killians.

From a 12 oz. stubby twist cap brown bottle with a blurb about the ale on the neck label and a "Best By" date on shoulder of bottle, 05/01/06. Made a good appearance, poured a red hued milk chocolate brown with a nice creamy pale tan head that reduced to a thin creamy lacing. Had more of a caramel/toffee malt aroma even though chocolate malts were used, hints of roasted barley and a piney, citric hoppiness. Medium carbonation and a slick, smooth light bodied mouth feel, very good drinkability. Had a big piney, citric hop taste with an underlining toffee maltiness and a dry, hoppy finish, a little nuttiness in the aftertaste.

12 oz. bottle, best by05/01/06.  Pours a clear reddish amber with a moderate-sized lasting creamy beige head (too many adjectives!). Aroma of toffee toasted malts, and some slight hop spiciness.  Taste is more of the same--definitely more malty than hoppy, with a lingering bitterness.  Been drinking Boulevard for years, and this is the first time Ive finally gotten around to getting the Irish ale.  Not bad at all.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: 12 oz bottle, via KUEric.  Pours a clear dark copper with a small fizzy white head.  Very small amount of sediment in bottle.  Aroma of toasted malt.  Fruity with touches of toffee and bread.  Flavor is lightly malty with a light bitter finish.  Kinda fruity with definate wheat character on the finish as well.  Light bodied with way too much carbonation.  An easy drinking beer, but not a whole lot to get excited about.  Mouthfeel was a little distracting with all the carbonation.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2006 12 oz Bottle: Pours a beautiful deep brown color, with a thick, four-fingered fluffy golden-reddish-brown head that lingered around for a good five minutes.  Although its an irish ale, I couldnt help but think this what a beer should like in a british pub -stupid american i suppose mixing the two, especially since my dad used to live in england.  Anyways, back to the beer, the aroma was carmel, malts, bread, apple sweetness.  The taste is appley, malty, hoppy, wheat, caramel, and slightly metallic.  TYhe taste warmed into a more hoppy beer than the original few sips.

Poured a dark red brown clear color with a small amount of fizzy white head.  Aroma is very nice and fruity with also caramel sweet hints.  Flavor is delicious, sweet malts, switches to a sharp hop flavor then back to a sweet caramel finish.  overall, definitely a good one.

Nice dark amber color,small white head that had a short hang time then faded leaving little behind.The aroma was malty caramel and some slight hops.The flavor comes off as much the same  but as it warms up the caramel becomes a little more pronounced and makes the brew a little more pleasant then it was.Very nice brew and hopefully this will be back in when in season not 8 months late  like in this one horse town.

Thanks doppelganger for the bottle! Red color, with creamy off-white head. Caramel malt aroma with a slightly metallic sense. Taste is surprisingly rich and sweet. Smooth malts and some hop balance and hints of citrus to make it pretty drinkable. Mouthfeel is crisp. Aftertaste is slightly roasty. Good stuff.
Bottled, thanks beerhandy! Nut brown. Aroma of cardamom & cinnamon. Roasty with light to medium body and soft mouthfeel. Below medium bitterness. A pleasant and well balanced very drinkable beer.

Ive rated this beer high in one sense because its so true to the best of what Ive seen from this style. Dark brown color with short head. Fierce carbonation and very liquid (not thin) body. Aroma is simple, straightforward malt, but the flavor ushers in more complex elements of mango syrup, lots of hops and cardamom seed. Very strong hop bitterness and fiery carbonation appear out of thin air on the palate. Compare this along with the perennial Harp product (an ok beer in its own right) and its an excellent introduction to the strongly-carbonated Irish style.
Pours a nut brown color with a small tan head.  Straight ahead aroma and flavor.  Very pleasant and easy to drink.  Very nice session ale.

Thanks to mjames for sending this one!
This Boulevard pours out a large off white head that slips into a dark amber beer.
Mild malt aroma that is echoed in the flavor. Not a complex or heavily done beer, this is an easy drinking quaffable brew which doesnt require any thought to enjoy.
bottle, color is a dark red. thin head. taste is roasted malt  and hops. has a thin smooth mouthfeel.

Bready aroma: sweet brown sugar, caramel, and apple perfume.  Rich looking, dark amber color with a thin ivory head.  Mildly sweet malty flavor with some buttery cardboard, then just a hint of pine hops in the finish.  Lively mouthfeel with a metallic finish.  Thanks to Doppelganger for the bottle.

Bottle courtesy of csbosox: Amber with ruby highlights, tan head.  Aroma is mildly malty with some hints of light fruit, caramel, and the barest of earthy/floral hops.  Light to medium bodied, seems to be a bit too thin and watery.  Taste is mild sweet malt (cereal, grain, caramel, cookie), a hint of earth, and a tiny bit of floral hops flavor.

Bottle from Cellars Minnetonka, MN. Mostly malty aroma with mild hop nose. Beautiful, dark, reddish amber with small, off-white head. Some lace. Roasted malt with enough hops to balance, although hops are certainly in the background. A solid brewpub beer and more flavorful than average for the style. In fact, I see that it is the 2nd highest rated beer in the style behind only Dublin 1798 Revolution Red. Creamy caramel notes come out about a quarter of the way in. A little higher in alcohol than the style calls for, but that is good, because as a fairly subtle sytle, the added strength helps it stand apart. This brew really improves as it warms. A pretty good brew.

Pours amber red with a small layer of khaki head. Low-level fruity aroma, with caramel, saltine crackers and a bit of pine. Body is much more lively and sparkly than the carbonation level would indicate. Good dry toastiness in flavor. Simple, but in a clean and drinkable way, not in a boring way. Just a bit of minty hops in the finish.

Nice amber colored brew with a fizzy layer of a head on top. Liveley carbonated. Medium intense malt and caramel nose, slightly sweet. Nice and warming nutty and caramel flavor in waves accompished by a nice light bitter kick in the middle. Thank you so much Csbosox for this beer.

Bottled... Poured a medium to dark red color with a medium head.  Aroma of sweet malt and caramel.  Flavor was sweet malt and a bit of spiciness with a nice hoppy finish.  Medium mouthfeel with good carbonation.

Sweet dough and caramell nose, ruddy amber color, low sticky head. Toaste malt, cookie, some raisin in the flavor. Broad tingly gritty bitter. Medium body, OK balance. OK but not that special overall.

Bottle 2005 Pub glass Tarnished copper with a thick fluffy off white head.Aroma is rich malt , toffee odors. Taste is malty nice caramel notes but plenty of fresh spicy hops that really balances this brew.Seasonal so get some when you can.
pours red with cream colored head. aroma is sweet, caramel, malty.  flavor matches the aroma, has a rich quality. good toastiness.
Beautiful crimson hue with delicate cream head.  Cherries, bready malt and a nuttiness are in the aroma.  The nutty flavor comes out more in the body, along with caramel.  Suprisingly dry finish.

St. Pats Day 2005, Crescent Moon Ale House (Omaha, NE).  On tap.  Pleasing.  Translucent dark red in the glass with quickly diminishing off-white head; great lacing, INCREDIBLE "racing."  I sat there playing with the glass for a full minute, just tilting it back and forth.  Not much of an aroma besides fresh/crisp pineish hops.  The flavor was dope-ish (i.e., almost amazing): subdued sweetness on the fluffy malt transitioned into a great level of bitter hops that lingered long into the finish.  Slightly buttery, smooth, well-balanced.  Perfect body: was stout enough to hold up the hops, but still felt crisp and light in the mouth without being watery.  Well done, Boulevard.  Well done.

Richly colored red beer with big waterfalling head that was sticky on the glass.  Nice.  Surprisingly sweet-wheaty aroma. Tingly and hoppy, sweet and tarter than I expected ... almost like a heartier American wheat.
(Bottle)  Pours a dark amber-brown body with an average-sized off-white head.  Aroma of malt, caramel, bread, and nuts.  Flavor of toasted bread, caramel, and cream.  Soft, creamy mouthfeel.
(bottle) Deep copper with almost no head. Malty aroma. Flavor has hints of sweetness with a definite hops background. Seems to be less than the sum of its parts.

Pours a dark copper with ruby tints and a lightly-lacing, light tan head.  Aroma has a nice crystal malty backbone with a hint of English hops.  Starts with a nice toasty malty thick body, a touch of toffee, and a sticky caramel finish.  A surely malty brew with enjoyable balance.  Thanks to csbosox for this!

Dark copper color with a small lid of light tan bubbles. Aromas of earth, nuts, esters, dark (near burnt) caramel, and touch of rubbery hops. Ive made this brew as a home-brew years ago. It was a brown ale that fermented out father than I wanted. Ended up thin and weak on the palate with flavors that did not seem to meld together, much like this brew. A light nut brown ale to me.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2005 Poured amber with an off white head. The aroma was very pleasant: fruity hops, orange peel, and pineapple. The flavor was really a huge let down on this one. Definately tons of other beers I would rather drink. Had a watery body with only a slight mix of grassy/floral hops for flavor. Very dry finish which is good because you will get this down fast that way.
Pours the color of a garnet stone.  Lively bubbles with small head.  No lacing.  Lively in the mouth as well.  Nice balance of malts and hops.  Good beer for a style I dont prefer.

612-850-0680.  Disregard those digits.  Beautiful dark burgundy hue with a small, thin and wispy head of foam.  Aroma screams of dry Irish Ale yeast, hints of herbs, flowers and citrus from the hops and a touch of fruit and caramel from the malt.  Taste is mainly hop accented with a blend of citrusy, flowery, herbaceous varieties along with a toasted malt and caramel malt backbone.  Dry and bitter.

thx to csbosox for this one.
copper colored with reddish highlights, slightly carmelly sweet w/ a touch of maltiness. A nice session beer

Thanks to beer handy for this.  Pours a mixture of deep copper and ruby with medium off-white head.  Aroma of malt, toffee, and floral esters.  Tastes malty, hoppy, with a solid fruit element.  Smooth palate with lively carbonation.

Thanks to csbosox for this brew,one of 23.Pours a dark reddish/garnet. has a nice malty nose with some soft hops coming in also.Something else,maybe a little caramel.Sweet but not SWEET,and a good blend with the roasted malts. A nice beer.Thanks Chris.

Pours translucent read with a small head and tiny bubbles.  Nose is mildy malty, sweet, a bit of sharpness.  Very flavorful with a nice sweet almost candy-like beginning, toasted malts and a smoky finish, with what tastes like crystal hops in the middle.  Great, lingering slightly smoky aftertaste.  Overall very good.

Pours murky red with smallish head.  No visible carbonation or lacing.  Smells of light malt and citrus.  I like the medium mouthfeel.  Not bad, maybe BBC can make some decent beers. (12 oz bottle/shaker)

Pours a deep red color. Small white head. Aroma is malty, with a hint of spice to it.  Flavor is sweet and malty,  roasted malt with some fruit and nuttyness.  Very nice brew. Thanks to Heemer for this one!

Brownish-red color with minimal head.  Aroma is warm, malty with toasted caramel and dark friut.  Flavor is very malty with toasted caramel, milk cream, dry bakers chocolate underpinning, and a nice balancing bitterness.
Deep brown color with a thin but foamy white head.  Malty aroma.  Good hefty mouthfeel, full of roasted malt with a hint of nut.  Slight hops to balance.  Terrific!

Brown Coloring. Small Head.  Aroma: Malt...Complex..  I agree with Pigfoot that it reminds one of a winter ale... Very Good Beer, But Wasnt Expecting the Wonderful Malt Flavoring to this Beer.  Roasts.. A bit of Spice... Very Nice!

Hey, thanks to Mjames for sending me this brew some time ago It was pretty damn tasty!

 Pours a dark cherry wood colored body, and a tan cap of head nice lacing after every vertical / horizontal / vertical motion of the glass! The aroma is somewhat spicy and malty at the same time. Big notes of wood chips with an underlying suggestion of cinnamon stick and cracked peppercorn. The flavor brought a lightly citric tartness.. then a sweet hint of molasses and toasted walnut and almond bagel in the finish- there was such a nice nutty presence here! The palate was rich and tempting. An unexpectedly enjoyable and drinkable ale!  Thanks again Mike!

Color: a clear reddish hue, and the head is short, off-white.
Aroma is a surprising delight, rich and ambrosial: caramel, nuts, some dark fruits, cherry, citrus, and an overall roasted feel. Puts me in mind of a barleywine or a winter ale, more than a typical Irish ale.
Tasty, warm texture. Hops are lying low, true to style. Malt is big, but not too much so. Taste is sweet and delicious. I loved this oned all the way down!

Deep mahogan color with light head. Floral hops with some sweet cherry and citrus notes.  Mouthfeel is quite rich with fine bubbles. Toffee, and chocolate are predominate but an evergreen hop quality shows on the mid and finish. Refreshing, yet lingering finish.
A decent selection. Quite hoppy, mild malts and other not so distinct flavors make this one quite complex. Quiet finish.

One of the best beers there is!  Another beer I wish was brewed/available longer, but it is always a special treat for the spring.  Nice color, pleasant odor, and it is one of the tastiest ales youll have.

Courtesy of MJames, couldnt get this in my home town. Came via Oklahoma. Big head out of the bottle. Eggshell, lacing. Citrusy, hoppy and smooth. Definite warming effect while consuming. Very Nice beer.
Deep copper in color with a small off-white head and large loose bubbles. Malty,earthy hop aroma. Sweet malt flavor with notes of caramel,subtle fruit, finishing malty and mildly sweet.
Clear red/orange color with a thin white head.  Sweet malty aroma, full bodied, sweet ending with a long aftertaste.
Pours a deep amber with a white creamy head. Some lacing. Slight diacetyl aroma. Lite hop bitterness with a crisp finish. Very carbonated. Thanks Mjames for the bottle for us NMers.

Nice amber body and thin soapy off-white head. Toasty malt aroma and mild woody hops. Malty flavor with some mild acidity that rounds it out nicely. Medium body. A decent Irish Ale. Thanks to TannerTavernboys for this.

Disclaimer, I have drank close to 60 bottles of this beer before RB: I'm still love the pour of this beer, nice deep copper hue with long lasting beige head and excellent head, just like I remembered. The aroma hints of toasted caramel malts with toffee tones, biscuit and bready, aromatic and grassy hops, light allspice, and dusty yeast esters. The taste starts malty sweet with a liberal notes of wildflowers and hayfield. Undertones of  mild pear, traditional bittering hops, and caramel. The finish display a nutty, grassy, and a sublime grapefruit tone. The mouthfeel is above average for style, smooth and creamy, nice! You would be hard pressed to find a better American made Irish ale styled beer. Very recommended.
Whaleman 2004: Pours reddish amber with a thin head. Light malt aroma. Nicely balanced malt and hops. A good beer. Very enjoyable.
A pretty good beer with a very hoppy flavor. I enjoyed the dark red body and its slight bitterness.
Nice, slightly malty aroma; beautiful cloudy red color; good flavor, slightly roasted, malty, just a hint of hops at the finish. Nice mild, easy drinking beer.

Scarlet amber in color with a dulled clearness, thin ivory head that fades to leave a bit of a collar, small spots and globs of lace stick. Aroma is toasty and grainy reminscent of Cheerios. Taste is toasted in the front, slightly dry and very mildly hopped in the back. There's a small twinge of bitterness just before the middle and light roasted nuttyness and subdued sweet malts skip in and out. Feel is a close to medium throughout with a nudge in the middle but kinda drops off from there and has a light fuzzy texture.
Kinda boring, but adequate, drinkable, sure, but passable.

Copper colored with a moderate head and fair lacing. Fresh spicy hop aroma that initially reminded me of a gin and tonic for some reason. Light to medium bodied with a toasty malt flavor, some bitterness and a chocolate note. Dryish finish.

Aroma is malty and nutty. Appearance is a reddish brown with a minimal head. Flavor is malty and sour with some grapes, oak, and cherries in the flavor. Somewhat light bodied with a smooth creamy taste. Not a bad Irish. Many thanks to CB and TAR for hooking me up with this and many other good beers!

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2004 bottle-thanks to Acrodizer for sending this my way.  pours a deep ruby red color with lots of roasted malt notes in the aroma.  some earty hops in there too.  flavor is somewhat weak, but decent roasted malts.  palate was medium.  As the beer warms, the hops come out more.  slight piney-ness and earthy kent goldings.  Spicey and very sweet.  slightly thin palate.  a farily solid offer from Boulevard and makes a good st. patricks day brew.
I was excited to try this and it looked great, however the taste never ended up sitting well.  Disappointed.

Unfiltered red rust. Scattered, rocky light tan head. Plummy malts placed over a bedding of phenolic esters and flowers. Fairly perfumey, chalky, and leafy with hints of unsweetened chocolate, butter rum, and roasted malt hulls. Soft-bodied. Gentle, bottle-conditioned spritz. Tangy malts and earthy hop flavors become slick and slightly rooty at the center. The maltiness becomes fully sweet and bready, late, with a hint of toffee backed with spicy hops. Finishes rooty and gingery with hints of wood, toffee, and lemon. Toffee malt profile lingers to accompany the light phenolic belches. Mediocre stuff, given the high level of acidity and notably bubbly mouthfeel.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Crisp. Hearty flavor with a strong hop flavor for a boulevard ale. You can drink a lot of this on St. Paddy's Day.
Light brown/red in coloration with a white head. A sharply malt aroma hinting at hops. nicely carbonated, perhaps a bit to much, makes the mouth tingle.
Really nice this year. Very balanced, nice carbonation to style, malty, with the Goldings citrus finish. Very refreshing; would make a good session beer.

Nice all around beer!!!
Too bad it's a seasonal.  It has a great red appearance.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2007 This has a beautiful amber color. Tried this again recently on tap. Its a nice brew. The aroma has some carmel, nuts and a little hint of apple. the body is a little highly carbonated, but I also find that in the bottle. The taste is slight apple with some caramel, iced tea and a little bit of citrus in the finish. A good brew. I am rating this again with the 2007 batch from a bottle. Nice light body and flavors are the same, but maybe a little more muted. A good session beer.
Amber in color with a nice frothy head. Aroma is sweet with floral notes. Flavor is sweet and lighty bitter. Well balanced. Liked this beer.
Pours a dark amber color with a medium tan head. Aroma is warm and malty. Flavor is equally malty with some caramel and a good balance of hops.

This is my favorite Irish Ale although it is made here in Missouri. Very tasty malt with caramel, a little sweetness. a good Irish style red ale. Too bad it is seasonal or i would buy this year round.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2011 Bottle (BB 05/15/11). Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white to light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is medium to dark amber.
Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted light bread, cookie),
lightly hoppy (flowers, apricot), with a light note of gum. Flavor is
moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly
sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Light to medium body,
watery  texture, lively carbonation. Boring but ok.

Thanks to MOBoy for the trade. Pours a beautiful rich dark amber color with a medium beige head. Aroma is pleasantly toasty and malty. Full sweet malt flavor with a touch of hops and caramel. Finish is sweet. Not bad at all.

Good looking, with frothy head and fine clarity in the body.  Neutral aroma.  Unexciting caramel malt flavor.  Finishes tight and dry.  THere is some appeal in its sour snap that comes in late, which actually accentuates some sweetness.
Medium brown color with tan head.  Very little aroma.  It is more malty than hoppy, but does taste much better than it smells.  Could definitley use more hop aroma.

reddish-brown color with a slight, but pleasant head. aroma is malt with a sweet slightly metallic quality. flavor is the star in this one. much more full-flavor than i expected..very malty with hints of brown sugar and a rich chocolatey finish.

rich roasty beer aroma, rich roasty malt flavor that is well balanced with hops.  

I'd say it has a pretty thick & silky mouthfeel & finish, medium to low carbonation, drank it pretty cold out of the bottle.  

Finish is greeted with some bite from the hops, a decent beer but is one of my least favorite Boulevard brews, if you like richer beers I'd highly recommend Bobs 47 or Bully Porter over this, just don't let these 200 calorie beers make ya fat.
Bright red color, almost exagerratedly malty. Nice caramel sweetness.  A very nice session ale.
Good beer.  Malty ale,with enough hops on the finish to make it interesting.  Thanks PhillyBeer2112!
Very much like a scottish ale, yet lacking the peat smoke hints. Very rich malt character; this is a very drinkable. The hopping was very English in character, and ramified throughout the tasting.
Rich, thick and malty. MMMM yeah. Sensationally smooth, yet complex and balanced. This is a style to sample more of.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2004 2003:It's Boulevard, so it's good, as always.  Pours a copper/gold color, smells hoppy and yeasty.  Fairly decent head, good lacing.  Ceamy mouthfeel.  Flavor moves from initial hop "snap", to a moment of dryness, to a mellow finish.  Very nice. 2004: Seems a little better than last year's.  Pours a deep red color, low carbonation, small head, a little lacing.  smells malty and yeasty.  Flavor is of great caramel malts, mild dryness, sweet malty ending, some lemongrass in there towards the end.  Good stuff, yet again.
Very nice Irish style beer.. Pours great with a decent head and the Aroma is mildly hoppy, followed by a decent taste

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2003 The first sighting of the Boulevard spring seasonal.  Pours copper with a big off-white frothy head.  Aroma is yeasty with smooth tones of hops.  My mouth first feels the carbonation and the frothiness, followed by a slight bitter hop taste, ending with a strange sweetness that is unlike any other beer I've tried.  This is a nice beer.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2004 A nicely balanced Irish-style amber ale, with caramel maltiness and  spicy, floral hop towards the finish.  Recipe for this one seems to vary annually a bit.  Certainly one of the most flavorful and all-around best Irish ales one is likely to find.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2003 Deep clear- amber in color, has a nice white head that doesn't last very long, light malty bready aroma. Sweet caremel malty flavor, mild hop profile it does have a nice clean dry finish, medium body, seems kind of bland, overall not all that bad but average.
Garnet in color; Head was large but fleeting; Pleasent nose of malt. A passable beer. Would be great in the right setting- perhaps the brewery or a patio full of hotties.

Very nice balance between malts and hops.  Im really not sure what an Irish Ale is but this reminded me of an American Amber Ale only with more subdued hops or else George Killians with hops. I really enjoyed.

Exceptional bottle-conditioned ale.  Most so-called Irish Ales are usually middle of the road red ales, but this is very nice.  The color is a nice red-amber, with a firm head and excellent lacing.  Aroma is caramel, with some herbal hops and a tinge of smokiness.  The flavor is perfectly balanced: caramel malt and Englishy hops, plus a slight smokiness.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Very very drinkable and characterful.
A good beer.  Hard to compare it to other irish ales as the only other irish beer I have had is guiness which isnt of the same style.

Wonderful representation of this obscure style. Real nice head, beautiful, stained-mahogany color. Some floaties from the bottle conditioning, but thats expected. Buttery nose. Smooth, woodsy taste, complemented with a burnt roastiness. Left behind a gentle smokiness and a mouthwatering sweetness... and a little hop zing, as if it were icing on the cake.

2002 version:  Absolutely wonderful.  IMO the best offering from this marvelous brewery.   Excellent malt flavor, beautiful appearance and appreciable head.  The only things I see need improvement are the lack of aroma and the fact that this is seasonal.
Good shot at a difficult style. Toasty, warming, and overall very pleasant.
